title: BIRT image iten rotates jpg images
body:
On BIRT 4.3.2 image report item when is filled with any jpg image using URI,file in shared resources,embedded image or Dynamic image shows the image rotated to left. This doesn't happen with others formats like png or gif.

Thanks

title: NA
body:
Welcome to the wonderful world of image formats!

Probably the image is a photo?
Can you share an example image here?

We could then test if the issue still persists with the current BIRT release 4.9.

Some cameras or smartphones are "clever": If you tilt the device by 90° to the left or to the right°, they notice this fact.
The hardware/software which is creating a JPEG from the raw camera sensor data always works in the same way regardless of whether you are creating a portrait or landscape photo.
When saving the JPEG, information about what is actually "up" is written to the EXIF metadata (or other metadata).

New image processing software usually knows about this metadata and uses it to rotate the decompressed image before presenting it to the user.

Older image processing software - as is used in BIRT 4.3.2 - does not know about this metadata and thus shows a rotated image if the device was tilted by +/-90°.

This is explained in more detail eg. here: https://jdhao.github.io/2019/07/31/image_rotation_exif_info/

You will need to pre-process such images before showing them in BIRT.

title: request : allow client to choose jndi.properties location
body:
We use birt as our reporting framework in a non-servlet application. We would like to use jndi to supply the connection. We used JndiKit to serve this. However, we were unable to convince birt to consume our properties file to reach the datasource, because it does not look in an amenable place for it.

Specifically, `JndiDataSource.getDriverJndiPropertyFile()` uses `OdaJdbcDriver.getDriverDirectory()` which uses `ManifestExplorer.getInstance().getDriverLocation()` . Because we use gradle to depend on the birt runtime and the mysql jdbc driver, this points to the jar in my gradle cache. : `file:/opt/workspace/gradle/caches/modules-2/files-2.1/com.innoventsolutions.birt.runtime/org.eclipse.birt.runtime_4.8.0-20180626/4.8.0/5fbd2fa6b165bb5b5493b2acdd6832257b97f5de/org.eclipse.birt.runtime_4.8.0-20180626-4.8.0.jar!/drivers` . Changing the birt home of the engine config to the working directory prefixes that directory to the previous filepath. I wasn't able to work around this issue by creating a folder of the same name as the jar, as I can not have a file and folder of the same name in a folder. Hence, I can't copy my jndi properties file without zipping it into the birt runtime jar itself until #625 works.

It would help for my use case - which I recognize is the minority - to allow programmatic configuration of some aspect of the birt engine, such that JndiDataSource can look for a jndi.properties file in an arbitrary location of the same filesystem.

It would also be nice if the complaint about jndi explained where it failed to find the properties file (with FINEST logging), given that it does check and lets InitialContext mistakenly suggest an environment variable.

title: NA
body: I am really a Gradle (and Maven) noob, but to me it it seems hazardous to depend on libraries in some cache directory *at runtime*. Is that common practice when using Gradle?

title: NA
body: That's what _intellij_ uses for a project with dependencies defined through gradle. I presume eclipse does something analagous. I don't know the driver directory used for an instance run with java.exe. I'll see if I can use jdb to answer that question.

title: NA
body: I assume your request is mostly about allowing to configure the location of `jndi.properties` and has nothing about build technology. What way of configuration do you have in mind?

title: NA
body:
For my use case, I recommend allowing a configuration before starting the platform, perhaps in `EngineConfig`.

I acknowledge that I am not familiar with Eclipse / Birt conventions. It looks like the closest they approach is `AbstractDataEngine.prepare()` receives appContext which contains "EngineTask" which contains `engine` which contains `config`. Prepare defines a dataset which gets a data set and then defines it. Defining a data set in `ModelDteApiAdapter` gets a data source and then defines it. If it were to add (relevant) information from the engine config to the datasource's properties, those will propagate down to `JndiDataSource` where get `getDriverJndiPropertyFile()` can check for a folder path, or fall back to the driver location, given that works for other use cases.

As long as I can add it programmatically, I don't have a strong opinion about how to define a jndi.properties filepath. I could give it to the runner just as easily as to the engine.

title: BIRT runtime uses Apache Cassandra library which as reported by NIST and NVD has critical security vulnerability
body:
Our security code and 3d party product review team reported that one of core BIRT ReportEngine runtime jars, e.g.:
org.eclipse.birt.runtime_4.10.0-20220721.jar or previous build version org.eclipse.birt.runtime_4.9.0-20220315.jar both use Apache Cassandra library - org.apache.cassandra:cassandra-thrift:1.1.0.

This library has critical (score 9.1) security vulnerability reported by NIST. For more details, please, see here: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44521. 

Thanks,
Aleksey
Deltek

title: NA
body:
The BIRT ReportEngine Runtime is not a web application. It is a local report renderer and, therefore, not subject to the effects described in your CVE. 

Please correct me if I am wrong

title: Excel error with large number of rows/groups
body:
I have a report with a large number of rows (18585) and a large number of groups (482).

Using the BIRT viewer I am able to generate a report using the XLSX emitter. However, when I open it Excel (2016) indicates there is a problem opening the file and it gives me a recovery option. When I select the recovery option it then gives me the following message:

```
Excel completed file level validation and repair. Some part of the workbook may have been repaired or discarded. 
Removed records: Named range from /xl/workbook.xml part (Workbook)
```

If I look inside the `/xl/workbook.xml` file I can see that it has a very long named expression. Please see [here](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/9430511/workbook.xml.txt).

When generating smaller reports, with fewer rows/groups I do not see this error, so I suspect the issue is to do with the the large number of rows/groups, and building the named expression for the grouping.

As a temporary workaround for the issue I removed the code inside the `uk.co.spudsoft.birt.emitters.excel.handlers.AbstractHandler.createName` method. This enabled me to run my large report without any errors from Excel.

title: NA
body:
Correct my if I'm wrong but it seems that in your special case the cells making up the name are a structure like this:

    xx
    xx
       xx
       xx
          xx
          xx

... and so on

It's not the *name* which is long, it's the cell range defined by the name.
A structure like this cannot be simplified (which was my first thought).

Next thought: Instead of just removing all the code inside the `createName` method, maybe you can use a UserProperty to decide wether to call skip the code or not.

By looking at the places from where `createName` is called, it seems like it is only called if a cell (or row, group, whatever) has a bookmark.

So it should be possible to easily avoid calls to `createName` if you just don't use bookmarks in your report.

Note that the bookmarks are Javascript expressions.
I don't know for sure if a `null` or `undefined` bookmark is treated like no bookmark at all, but you can test that of course. Given that's the case, you could use any condition you like in your report to avoid bookmarks for the huge reports.

title: NA
body:
Regarding the bookmarks, In my test there were no explicitly defined bookmarks. On the grouping itself there was no bookmark defined and neither were there any bookmarks defined elsewhere in the report.

I also experimented by setting the bookmark on the group to `null` or `undefined` (instead of no value) and that didn't seem to help.

It seems to me that when I added the grouping to the report it implicitly added a bookmark into the report. I'm guessing a little bit here.

title: NA
body: Just to be clear: So you *.rptdesign XML source (and *.rptlibrary XML, if used) does not contain any `<bookmark` text?

title: NA
body:
Yes, that is correct. They do not contain any `<bookmark>` elements.

I can see some references to a toc. For example there is one in the group header which looks like `<structure name="toc"/>`. But I don't know if that would be causing any issues.

title: NA
body:
I actually managed to reproduce the issue on a simplified report which does not do any grouping.

The attached [report](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/9431122/test7.rptdesign.txt) uses data from the ClassicModels database. The Data Set query is a bit silly, but I was just looking for something simple to reproduce the issue.

title: NA
body:
Yes! That's it!
The TOC entries are also bookmarks and they are causing this issue.
TOC entries are generated automatically. To avoid creating TOC entries, you have to clear the corresponding field in the group editor dialog.
Sorry, didnt' see your latest comment. My answer is regarding the "toc" entries.

title: NA
body:
> I actually managed to reproduce the issue on a simplified report which does not do any grouping.
> 
> The attached [report](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/9431122/test7.rptdesign.txt) uses data from the ClassicModels database. The Data Set query is a bit silly, but I was just looking for something simple to reproduce the issue.

I just found that If I modify this report to use an Auto Layout and disable page breaks then the error goes away.

Also, with my original report (which uses grouping), if I disable page breaks on the group, then the Excel error also goes away too.

What I'm trying to achieve is have a report which uses groups, where each new group will be displayed on a separate page. It seems that when I'm using page breaks, this causes Birt to automatically add each page into the named range which causes issues when there are large number of groups/page breaks.

title: NA
body:
I've created a new [report](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/9439784/test.rptdesign.txt) which demonstrates the underlying issue. This report uses grouping and Page Break After is set to 'Always Excluding Last'. There is no (explicit) usage of bookmarks or TOC in the report.

When this report is exported to Excel you should be able to see the error in my first comment.

Some observations:
 * Error case - If I have the page break enabled on each group, then it seems like `AbstractRealTableHandler.endTable` gets called once per group (611 times) and this is creating/updating a bookmark each time it is called.
 * Working case - If the page break on the group is set to 'Auto', then `AbstractRealTableHandler.endTable` is called 2 times - I think this is because 2 page breaks get automatically created for the report.

> Next thought: Instead of just removing all the code inside the `createName` method, maybe you can use a UserProperty to decide wether to call skip the code or not.
> 
> By looking at the places from where `createName` is called, it seems like it is only called if a cell (or row, group, whatever) has a bookmark.

Yeah, my original approach was a dirty hack to troubleshoot the issue. Would it best to have a UserProperty or should it be a property which is passed into the emitter? 

EDIT: Sorry I had to make a few edits to this comment to use a better example.

title: NA
body:
I think I found a workaround which does not involve modifying the BIRT emitter code.

Earlier I tried setting the group bookmark expression to `null` to no avail.

This time I set the table bookmark expression to `null` and this appears to have addressed the issue! When the table bookmark expression is set to `null` then no named ranges are created in the `workbook.xml` file.

title: NA
body: I'll close this issue then.

title: NA
body:
Hello Together,

I confirm there is an issue with the rcp-designer. I started some retests with the same configuration like above with JVM11.

**Processing of PS error message:**

![BIRT-PS-error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41593722/189985555-097df51a-14d7-4575-a139-be65756dd96d.png)

**Processing PDF - result is an empty PDF:**

![BIRT-PDF-error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41593722/189985708-f13e5605-098b-4755-a46b-d06a984b5cbe.png)

Both errors are reproducable with the BIRT-viewer and with the direct processing call from the designer (without designer).
The other output formats can be produced correctly.


**Regression test (manual) BIRT 4.9 with the "all-in-one"-designer (JVM11):**
- PDF-document created correctly
- PS-document ended in error above

**Regression test (manual) BIRT 4.8 with the "all-in-one"-designer (JVM8):**
- PDF-document created correctly
- PS-document created correctly

Can somebody assists with it. It seams to be an issue with the SOAP-service requests or the emitter service registration.

Best regards

title: Birt 4.9 Runtime gives error when deployed
body:
Hello,
I downloaded the BIRT RUNTIME from https://download.eclipse.org/birt/downloads/drops/R-R1-4.9.0-202203161719/birt-runtime-4.9.0-20220315.zip. When we deployed BIRT war, it gave us error, after carefully examination, we found inside birt.war\WEB-INF\lib\javax.xml.rpc_1.1.2.v202203150031.jar file there was javax.xml.rpc-api-1.1.2.jar inside the jar file. When we removed and re-deployed the Runtime worked correctly. 
My question is 
a) are you aware of this issue already?
b) do you have new version release of Birt Runtime
Thanks

UtilMisc.toMap("samplingTypeId", null);

````
public static <V, V1 extends V> Map<String, V> toMap(String name1, V1 value1) {
         return populateMap(new HashMap<String, V>(), name1, value1);
     }
````

title: NA
NA
body:
Can you confirm that you are running Birt with Java11?
The error message seems strange.

title: NA
body:
You said that your `fetch` event looks like this:

    UtilMisc.toMap("samplingTypeId", null);

Of course this is a BIRT bug (the stack trace definitey looks like some internal error), but you should read the stack trace:

    Caused by: org.eclipse.birt.data.engine.core.DataException: Data Set script method "Fetch" returned null; expected a Boolean value.

Your `fetch` event doesn't use `return true;` or `return false;`

The meaning is: "Did we find a record or are we after the last record?"

So in the first place, it is an error in your script.

title: NA
body:
@claesrosell 
I use java11 to run and java17 to run

title: NA
NA
body: Personal guess, when the parameter is null, the reflection method fails

title: NA
body:
> Personal guess, when the parameter is null, the reflection method fails

Which sounds logical.
I think that Java generics and Rhino cannot work together well.

In Javascript, null ist just null.
It's not a null String, a null Integer, a null (you name it).

I wonder how this could even work with BIRT 4.3.

title: NA
body:
I don't know, the script code has not changed, just upgrade BIRT 4.3.2 to 4.9.0.

I subsequently modified the toMap method parameter declaration with no errors.

title: NA
body:
According to this bug: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=562582 ICU support in Eclipse should be removed with the 2022-06, release. So the time seems right for this error to appear. 

I am not at all familiar with ICU, but to my understanding com.ibm.icu.util.ULocale is the "enhanced version" of java.util.Locale . The error message "Access restriction: The type 'ULocale' is not API" seems strange since ULocale probably is API, from ICU's perspective. The visibility of the packages must have been altered with the latest version of the platform.

A search for "import com.ibm.icu" in the Birt workspace produces 985 matches.  Some migration to core java can probably be automated, but it is still a big job.

title: NA
body:
Same semi-knowledge here: ICU is an enhancement for Java's builtin I18N capabilities.

A possible way to handle this could be:

As a first step, remove all import `com.ibm.icu...` statements from the source code and remove the ICU library.

Then work like this: search for ULocale, add an import java.util.Locale to these files and replace ULocale with Locale.

And so on for other classes - for most if not all of them there should be a corresponding class in Java's builtin libraries.

Hopefully there will be only few cases where such an exact replacement is not possible, or none at all.

That should make the build process work with some effort.

If every edge case actually works like before, that's a different question, see for example the comment in the bug Claes mentioned.

title: NA
body:
It looks like we are pulling ICU from maven, so my initial guess that the visibility of ULocale had been changed in the Eclipse Platform is probably wrong. 

I also see that the format for maven dependencies in target platform files has changed some. Do we need to update Tycho as well? 

Looking in the PDE, the "org.eclipse.birt.core.ui" actually doesn´t have access to com.ibm.icu.util seems strange that this has worked earlier.

![bild](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8941815/191232798-b4903077-20c7-4929-9c9c-96c6e66bd079.png)

title: NA
body:
The wiring is gone mad a bit. BIRT is very fond of re-exporting dependencies (which I hate).

org.eclipse.birt.core.ui imports icu in the package imports but it already gets the import from birt.core which re-exports icu. Simply removing the re-export causes a lot of errors.

title: NA
body:
Yes. org.eclipse.birt.core re-exports ICU with another set of access rules:

![bild](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8941815/191247310-98107159-3c2c-490a-95f1-44248f7cd773.png)

I agree, re-exporting is generally not a good idea.

title: NA
body: org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.oda is dependent on ULocale and exposes it via API, which we are consuming. Currently, it would not be possible to remove ICU4J.

body: I have fixed the ICU issue.

title: Cannot create a new Driver Class needed for my Data Source
body:
I have the jar, and I "add" it using the Manage Drivers screen when trying to create my Data Source.

I can see the jar appears in the ~/drivers directory, but I would expect that a new Driver Class Name would appear in order that it then show in the dropdown menu so that I can properly create my Data Source. 

[AddNewDriver.docx](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/9629939/AddNewDriver.docx)

title: NA
body:
Please don't add proprietary file formats here.
You can add screenshots etc directly to your answers.

title: NA
body:
I cannot get the Driver Class dropdown to populate.

I can add the jar, or even manually place it in the plugins directory, and yet the Driver Class dropdown never changes and never shows me my driver.

title: NA
body:
I am using the Oracle JDBC driver by manually putting ojdbc7.jar into plugins\org.eclipse.birt.report.data.oda.jdbc_*.v*\drivers directory (the * are depending on the BIRT release).
This should work for any JDBC driver.
Maybe your driver  JAR file has additional dependencies (other Java classes or DLLs) and the JVM fails to find these?

title: NA
body:
Yes.  That worked and I think it must be some incompatibility issue.  I had been trying to use the ojdbc10 jar.  I was thinking that perhaps BIRT (birt-rcp-report-designer-4.8.0-20180626-win32.win32.x86) can only use the ojdbc7.jar? I tried a few more times with the "10", and it would not take it.   

I downloaded birt-rcp-report-designer-4.9.0-20220315-win32.win32.x86_64, and I know I have java 64, that wont start and that may be a separate issue with 32 vs 64.  I had wanted to test my theory that perhaps ojdbc10 would work with that.    BUT..I am happy to have a working BIRT, as I need to get on with my real task.  Thanks for your help.

title: NA
body:
Don't know, but probably you should look at https://www.oracle.com/database/technologies/faq-jdbc.html.
In fact, the ojdbc driver version you should use is depending on the JDK version and the RDBMS version.

Oracle JDBC can use the thin driver (pure Java) or a C-based driver (based on ODPI or classic OCI). The latter also needs DLLs.
But AFAIK you would notice missing DLLs for the OCI driver only when you actually try to connect.

title: Export word/pdf, how to add/generate table of contents (TOC)?
body: need help

title: NA
body:
If you mean an automatically generated *visible* TOC: No!

You can create a visible TOC with clickable links yourself (using hyperlinks and bookmarks).
But you won't be able to render the corresponding page numbers in the TOC.

title: NA
body: OK, thanks

title: NA
body:
@hvbtup 
Is it possible to customize the value of parameter "tocLevel "?

title: NA
body:
I don't think so.

If you mean the maximum level for the TOC: Just avoid creating TOC entries which you don't want.
TOC entries are created manually in the group editor dialog, but you can clear the field in the dialog.

The level at which a TOC entry is generated is computed automatically from the layout structure.

title: NA
body:
example:
```
1 xxx (This is a label, the value of toc is "1 xxx")
1.1 xxx (This is a label, the value of toc is "1.1 xxx")
1.1.1 xxx (This is a label, the value of toc is "1.1.1 xxx")
```
After exporting word
```
{ TC"1 xxx"\f C \l "1"}
1 xxx
{ TC"1.1 xxx"\f C \l "1"}
1.1 xxx
{ TC"1.1.1 xxx"\f C \l "1"}
1.1.1 xxx
```
I hope it is
```
{ TC"1 xxx"\f C \l "1"}
1 xxx
{ TC"1.1 xxx"\f C \l "2"}
1.1 xxx
{ TC"1.1.1 xxx"\f C \l "3"}
1.1.1 xxx
```
That's why I want to manually set the tocLevel value

title: NA
body:
You would have to use (kind of artificial) groups then.
But I don't know if the Word emitter uses these like the PDF emitter.

title: NA
body:

1 xxx (label)
1.1 xxx (label)
1.1.1 xxx (label)

to 
```
1 xxx (table > group -> label)
1.1 xxx (table > group -> label)
1.1.1 xxx (table > group -> label)
```

Our reports are often nested 4 or 5 levels of list/table items plus a handful of groups.

FWIW, you can also git revert the merge commit. You would have to do this on the current repo state, not on the state that you have already reset. But I cannot say if the owners would prefer to not have the commit in the history at all.
```
git revert c38c2bd14252245fe272385d63c8eb271455cdc3
git push
```

title: Assert errors on Report Design parsing on Render task creation
body:
Hello, 

We are facing various assert errors when we tests our reports with assertions enabled (ie -ea JVM flag)
This is happening when we create a render task and the Birt Engine tries to open and parse the report design. The simplest way to reproduce the issue is to define a themes.rptlibrary with a custom theme defined (linked to a css file) and apply the theme to the report design.
When testing the report with -ea flag set we get the following stack trace:
```
java.lang.AssertionError
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ReportElementState.checkContainer(ReportElementState.java:206)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ReportElementState.addToSlot(ReportElementState.java:259)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ReportElementState.initSimpleElement(ReportElementState.java:450)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ReportElementState.initElement(ReportElementState.java:345)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ThemeState.parseAttrs(ThemeState.java:87)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ModuleParserHandler.startElement(ModuleParserHandler.java:261)
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.startElement(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.AbstractXMLDocumentParser.emptyElement(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanStartElement(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl$FragmentContentDispatcher.dispatch(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanDocument(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.XMLParser.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserImpl$JAXPSAXParser.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.apache.xerces.jaxp.SAXParserImpl.parse(Unknown Source)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ModuleReader.readModule(ModuleReader.java:98)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.DesignReader.read(DesignReader.java:88)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.core.DesignSessionImpl.openDesign(DesignSessionImpl.java:309)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.api.SessionHandleImpl.openDesign(SessionHandleImpl.java:294)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.api.SessionHandle.openDesign(SessionHandle.java:1)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.parser.ReportParser.getDesignHandle(ReportParser.java:158)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportEngineHelper.getReportDesignHandle(ReportEngineHelper.java:255)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportEngineHelper.openReportDesign(ReportEngineHelper.java:274)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportEngine.openReportDesign(ReportEngine.java:619)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportDocumentReader.loadReportRunnable(ReportDocumentReader.java:880)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportDocumentReader.getOnPreparedRunnable(ReportDocumentReader.java:937)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportDocumentReader.getOnPreparedRunnable(ReportDocumentReader.java:1)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.EngineTask.getOnPreparedRunnable(EngineTask.java:263)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.RenderTask.initRenderTask(RenderTask.java:149)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.RenderTask.<init>(RenderTask.java:115)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.RenderTask.<init>(RenderTask.java:98)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportEngineHelper.createRenderTask(ReportEngineHelper.java:502)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.ReportEngine.createRenderTask(ReportEngine.java:518)
```
We noticed that the error doesn't happen if we pass the IReportRunnable of the report design to the IRenderTask.createRenderTask method. It seems that in this case the parsing is bypassed, but then the generated pdf contains many unexpected layout issues that may be caused by the fact that some dynamic design changes via the API are not applied.

When running the report without the IReportRunnable argument in the createRenderTask method, and without the -ea flag the report is generated correctly. However the fact that there are AssertionError thrown when runing with -ea flag indicates either a misuse/misconfiguration of the engine or a bug in the engine.

title: Support for json data source
body:
short version: add support for JSON data source, similar to the support available for xml data.

long story:

I have been a long term user of BIRT (from 2002 to 2010), and was forced to move to other solution, as the product went side way under actuate/opentext. Happy to see it coming back, as it was one of my favorite.

One of the major limitation was JSON support.

During Opentext days as BIRT main contributor, a very buggy data source for JSON was introduced. I  I did not look at the current 4.10 version (will do in coming weeks). Does anyone know what is the state of the JSON dara source ? The XML data source was much more powerful (and reliable), and we used to convert json to xml, and generate report. 

If the json data source is not usable/abandoned - possible to fix it ? If not, I wonder if possible to clone the XML data source, replace the XML parser with JSON parser. XPATH path with jsonpath, and have a reporting tool capable of connecting with modern rest services. Even if the temporary solution will be to internally convert json to xml it will be a big win. 

considering built in JavaScript with RHINO, will be a big upside.

there is a commercial json data source from data. Never tried it.

title: Decimal data type controls are not printing correctly - the data is getting cut off and rounded.
body:
Create a simple data control of Decimal type in a report. Set control value to "1111111111111112.12". Print/preview report in Eclipse/View Report/Web Browser. See simple report design and report output attached. 
Note that the data is getting cut and rounded. If I remove 1 digit and make precision = 17 instead of 18, then it prints correctly. Is there as limit on BigDecimal precision data type in BIRT?
[decimal_not_printing.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/9822528/decimal_not_printing.zip)
![decimal_not_printing_viewer](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17771801/196753132-77655160-32f0-4fdc-8094-68bf3fa13f21.png)
The issue happens in old BIRT 4.9 (Java 8) and new BIRT 4.9 (Java 11).

If you run/print the same number in Java 8 or 11 it prints correctly:
BigDecimal d = new BigDecimal("1111111111111112.12");
System.out.println(d);

title: NA
body: Write me. I added an email to my profile.

title: NA
body:
After debugging your example I draw this conclusion:
Javascript numeric literals is translated to double:s in Rhino (the javascript engine that Birt use). That double is later converted to a BigDecimal by Birt. It is the String to double convertion that looses the precision in this example.

title: NA
body:
Thanks for looking into that. In real life example we ran across this issue with total (aggregate) controls. And the totals (both table bindings and controls) are also defined as Decimal data type. Probably, the internal scripting is also doing double conversion in  between and then BIRT classes convert the end result into BigDecimal.
Is there any way to fix that or is that part of rhino scripting which is beyond the scope?

title: NA
body: After "reading up" on numbers in javascript they seem to be double precision floats, which means that the Rhino implementation is correct.

title: NA
NA
body:
> After "reading up" on numbers in javascript they seem to be double precision floats, which means that the Rhino implementation is correct.
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
Well, I understand the floating math and get it that in a lot of cases it is no good for financial calculations. But that is why you have Decimal (BigDecimal) data type.  My understanding was that if you use Decimal control in BIRT it should display the number as it is w/o any internal conversion to double and then back to BigDecimal. That seems to be not the case and as the result you end with the wrong number. Each time decimal values are converted to double before any calculation and formatting the number may lose the precision aspect of the Decimal data type (which is really what Decimal type is designed for).

We occasionally run across such issues in BIRT reports though we are using only Decimal data type for DataSource/DataSet columns, aggregates/totals and report controls.
The suggestion to calculate totals/aggregates in SQL instead of doing the same via report engine seems to be quite an overreach...What for would need a report engine then???
Finally, found this discussion from old days about BIRT fully supporting BigDecimal calculations - https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=155138.
Thanks

title: NA
body:
> Finally, found this discussion...

I wish the final conclusion of that discussion would be true...

I agree this is a bug which is still not fixed.

> Probably, the internal scripting is also doing double conversion in between and then BIRT classes convert the end result into BigDecimal.

To be precise: AFAIK it is not scripting done in Rhino which is causing this error. It's caused by the Java implementation in the source files I mentioned (and other source files for other aggregate functions).

> Is there any way to fix that or is that part of rhino scripting which is beyond the scope?

As this is caused on the Java side, it should be possible to fix it (in the abovementioned source files).

But I doubt that anyone will fix it (unless you fix it yourself by providing a PR), because it would be quite an effort:

I think it would be necessary to support all the calculations in two different ways:
a) for number objects with a binary based representation (using Java's `double` or `Double` internally).
b) for number objects with a decimal based representation (using Java's `BigDecimal` internally).
... and to take care of the possible case that these types of numbers are mixed in the calculations (e.g. by coercing to `BigDecimal`).

Furthermore, if you actually do any financial computations in Javascript (not BIRT aggregates), you're probably doomed:
As Claes said and according to https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_numbers.asp, numbers in Javascript are always IEEE 754 `double`.

A workaround which avoids most of these problems is to use CT (instead of EUR or USD) as your basis (see http://adripofjavascript.com/blog/drips/avoiding-problems-with-decimal-math-in-javascript.html).
For division (e.g. German VAT computation `x * 19 / 100`), there is still a possible error, because AFAIK Javascript uses round-half-even mode for numbers, which is absolutely OK for scientific computations to avoid a statistical bias, but for rounding in invoices, the norm EN 16931 for example prescribes mercantile rounding (round up 0.5 to 1 for positive numbers, round down -0.5 to -1 for negative numbers).

title: NA
body:
As a side note, the Classic Models example database built into BIRT is a classic example for wrong database model design:
It uses SQL FLOAT data types for BUYPRICE (probably because the embedded database engine does not support decimal based numbers). Database columns for prices should use a decimal based number type in the DB as well and the DB should use mercantile rounding mode for such numbers.

title: NA
body:
I looked at this again, and the original problem happens because the script is using a javascript number literal which cannot "translate" to a corresponding double value. If the one would need an exact value the script needs to create a BigDecimal instead. Javascript does not have a corresponding type so the way to do that is:
`new java.math.BigDecimal("1111111111111112.12");` instead of the `1111111111111112.12` literal. Just setting the Birt datatype to "Decimal" is not enough since it will be instantiated with the floating point value from the javascript expression.

With that said: There are bugs or at least lack of function in BIRTs calculations. These are highlighted by @hvbtup in one of the comments. The aggregator functions of BIRT does not use BigDecimal where appropriate. The aggregator functions (AggrFunction) that use decimals all has "DataType.DOUBLE_TYPE" set as datatype. This will select a the "NumberCalculator" and that calculator always converts numbers to doubles in calculations.

There are currently no way for the report designer to define what precision that should be used. It is possible to define the datatype for a "computed column" in a dataset, but that information is not taken into account (nor available) when the ICalculator, that will perform the calculations, is selected. The datatype only affects the resulting datatype. This means that all calculations will be done with doubles and then converted to the selected datatype.

I see three different ways forward:

a) Change the aggregator functions that needs higher then double precision to "Decimal", so a BigDecimalCalculator is selected for calculations during aggregation. 
b) Take the result datatype (selected be the report designer) into account when selecting calculator. Basically, if the return type is Decimal and the AggrFunction is "DataType.DOUBLE_TYPE", select BigDecimalCalculator, otherwise do as before.
c) For the aggregator functions that may need higher then double precision, take the result datatype (selected be the report designer) into account when selecting calculator. Basically, if the return type is Decimal and the AggrFunction is "DataType.DOUBLE_TYPE", select BigDecimalCalculator, otherwise do as before.

To solve the `x * 19 / 100` problem, if done in Javascript one would need to write an expression like this:
`(new java.math.BigDecimal("101010")).multiply(new java.math.BigDecimal("0.19"), java.math.MathContext.DECIMAL128)`

@hvbtup if I were to try to "close" https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=155138 again could you provide me with a test report that reproduces all the known BigDecimal problems? I am aware of the aggregation functions and the Javascript literals, but are there others?

title: NA
body:
I won't be able to create such a test report in November.

The topic of proper calculation is actually quite complex.

I'll try to collect some brief notes here about what can go wrong:

* First of all, implicit conversion is the cause of so many errors in all kinds of software. I really wish all programming languages would forbid them.
* A conversion from a 10-based number representation to or from a 2- (or 16-) based number representation will almost always result in precision loss due to conversion errors. E.g. you cannot a value like 0.1 (1/10) exactly as a float or double.
* For most computations, there are several different ways to correctly calculate them if we assume we can store all numbers exactly. But in reality, we cannot store numbers exactly, and thus in reality the resulting errors depend *very much* on the way we perform the calculation due to rounding errors. That's what the mathematical discipline "numerics" is all about - to perform calculations that the unvoidable rounding errors have minimal impact on the end result.
* It makes a difference *when* we round. As a simple example, say we have to exact input values 1/2 and 1/2. Our end result should be an integer. If we can compute with the exact values and round afterwards, we get 1/2 + 1/2 = 1.0 = 1. But if we round the individual values, then 0.5 will be rounded up to 1, so the result is 1+1 = 2.

As a result of what I said above, your wording "higher precision than double" is not correct. 
Usually nobody needs higher double precision in a calculation. 

One would use float (or double) variables if the values are usually not exact anyway, e.g. they are measures (in the sense that someone has actually measured something, e.g. the alcohol contrentration of a liquor).
In such a case, one usually should store all measured values as doubles (unless they describe *counting* something) and perform all calculations with the double datatype and round-half-even rounding mode, and store the result as double. Only in the last step, when presenting the result to a user, the result has to be converted from double (2-based) into a decimal representation. In this last step, conversion error is inevitable. But all the calculations are then good from a numerical point of view, if we take as given that we can store numbers only with limited memory size (in bytes).

But when the calculations are about offers/invoices/taxes/money, then we must use decimal datatypes and (usually) round-half-up from the start to the end. That means all intermediate results must be stored in decimal form, too.

*This "commercial" kind of calculation avoids all conversion errors, but it still incurs rounding errors.*

So it's not "higher precision than double", but instead a slightliy different way of performing the calculation to avoid conversion errors.

title: NA
body: I'm going to see what I can do with this.  At least the part about getting it to use BigDecimalCalculator in aggregates.  The OP's example involving constant values is going to be a different solution.

title: NA
body:
It is possible to change the calculator in the onRow method, once it's known that the incoming data is a BigDecimal, however the return datatype of SUM would still be float and the user would need to know to change the datatype of the aggregate column binding from float to decimal.   I wonder if it would be better to have a parallel set of aggregators specifically for decimal return values, such as DECIMAL_SUM.  Maybe as an optional plugin.

Additionally, there are some things the user would need to know to do for commercial/financial reporting, such as using new BigDecimal() for constant values and always using BirtMath for computations.  These could be documented in the plugin GitHub page.  

I think BIRT should support financial reporting, even if it requires users to do things a bit differently.  You can't necessarily rely on a SQL backend to do it for you.

title: NA
body:
E.g. for SUM:
We have got the information which datatype the colum is (from the dataset metadata resp. the binding metadata).

Shouldn't it be possible to let the internal calculations use something like `T <extends Number>` for the calculations?

And perhaps we should give an opportunity to explicitly specify a rounding mode for the calculations. If not specified, it should be inferred from the data type, e.g. float -> ROUND_HALF_EVEN, decimal -> ROUND_HALF_UP.

+1 for BIRT should support financial reporting.

Anyway, we kind of hijacked this ticket. Maybe it makes sense to change the title.

body:
I've added DECIMALSUM and DECIMALAVG to our birt-functions-lib plugin project:  https://github.com/innoventsolutions/birt-functions-lib/tree/birt-4.14
and they work nicely.  The site URL is https://github.com/innoventsolutions/innoventsolutions.github.io/raw/4.14.1/4.14.
I'll be building out the rest of the aggregates that suffer from rounding errors due to float calculations over time and will note in this ticket as I progress.

title: NA
body:
I've added 19 aggregations that use decimal calculations to the Innovent Solutions birt.functions.lib plugin.  The site URL is the same one we've been using for several years:  https://innoventsolutions.github.io/2.5.2.  The aggregations are in a separate category so they are optional.  The wiki URL is https://innoventsolutions.github.io.  (I'll be adding wiki content soon).  The repo URL is https://github.com/innoventsolutions/birt-aggregations-lib.

I believe that using these aggregations and using BirtMath for calculations and new BigDecimal for constant values should allow on to produce financial reports devoid of floating point errors.  If you get a chance to use them, let me know what you think.  Please post issues to the repo if you have any problems.

title: Birt runtime.jar has embedded many 3rd party libs
body:
org.eclipse.birt.runtime_4.10.0-20221001.jar has embedded:
- Apache Commons lang
- slf4j
- W3C Tidy
- Apache Cassandra
- and many others

This makes it easy to have clashes with other dependencies.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6008104/198044374-59311254-e958-487f-bb28-3f2f3afd57e5.png)

title: NA
body:
I'm explicitly not an expert here, but...

The idea of the BIRT runtime distribution is to have every dependency included, in a combination that actually works.

You can consider using the OSGI runtime. OSGI promises to solve such compatibility issues (just like modularization in never Java versions), allowing you to use different releases of the same library in different parts of your program.

You can also consider running BIRT in a separate process (e.g. use Tomcat with the BIRT viewer and use BIRT's HTTP API to run reports).

title: NA
body:
Many of the listed libraries are excluded with the latest built like Cassandra, slf4j, guava, hector.
Tidy is updated to a new version.

title: Outdated update site links in features
body:
I noticed that the feature jar org.eclipse.birt.engine.runtime_4.10.0.v202210011458.jar had `feature.xml` with

```
   <url>
      <update label="%updateSiteName" url="http://download.eclipse.org/birt/update-site/4.9"/>
      <discovery label="%updateSiteName" url="http://download.eclipse.org/birt/update-site/4.9"/>
   </url>
```
so the wrong update site.

Running [Search for `update-site` on GitHub birt](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/search?p=1&q=update-site) shows quite a few other cases where the update site reference has not been changed for a new version of BIRT.

These should be updated for each release (not sure what to do while developing 4.11 as the 4.11 update site won't be live, but it probably doesn't matter as developers will know that and can fix it if needed.)

title: "java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot find the ODA dataSource extension..." critical error with new BIRT 4.11 on JDK/JRE 11
body:
We have custom created Datasource/Dataset ODA extension that fails on latest BIRT 4.11 build. 
Steps:
1) download and install birt-report-designer-all-in-one-4.11.0-20221120-win32.win32.x86_64.zip from https://download.eclipse.org/birt/downloads/drops/latest/. E.g., c:\eclipse_411.
2) run eclipse/birt designer using jre 11, e.g., C:\eclipse_411\eclipse.exe -vm "C:\oracle\jdk-11.0.15\bin\javaw.exe"
3) open workspace "oda" and export/build 2 plugins: com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.designer_1.0.0.jar and com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.runtime_1.0.0.jar. 
Workspace "oda" attached - 
[eclipse_411_workspace.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/10105781/eclipse_411_workspace.zip)

Built plugins also attached - 
[plugins.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/10105787/plugins.zip)
4) copy 2 new plugins under your eclipse home/plugins folder, e.g., c:\eclipse_411\plugins
5) open workspace "reports" (attached in #3) and open syrusr.rptdesign attached - 
[rpt_lib.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/10105827/rpt_lib.zip).
Note that rptdesign file references libraries (also attached above).
6) Go to report outline->DataSources and DataSets and note that CP_DataSource and DataSet are in red error state. Double click on DataSet and then click on "Property Bindings" -->> error occurs:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot find the ODA dataSource extension (com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.runtime).
 Check the workspace log file for any problems with loading the extension bundle and its dependencies.
	at org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.oda.util.manifest.ManifestExplorer.getExtensionManifest(ManifestExplorer.java:200)....
Complete error attached - 
[error.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/10105884/error.txt)

The same steps, same ODA extension/plugins are working just fine with BIRT 4.9 released on 4/2022.
Thanks,
Aleksey
Deltek Inc.

title: NA
body:
I figured out the reason of your issue and you can fix it by your self.
**But currently I cannot say why this effect happens.**

I have the same issue with BIRT_4.8 an plugin-files which are built only with JDK8 without compatibility mode of other JDKs or of >= JDK11.
I see in your MANIFEST.MF that you have the same environment issue:

![plugin-MANIFEST-JDK1 8](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41593722/204366859-eafad939-2c25-412b-82a6-842f7b4f86a9.png)

The issue happens because due to the JSE1.8 the "org.eclipse.equinox.simpleconfigurator" doesn't create the bundle.info correctly.

So you have to add 2 lines manuelly with the according path (changed to your path):

01) path: C:\BIRT_4.11\eclipse\configuration\org.eclipse.equinox.simpleconfigurator

02) add the 2 plugin lines
com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.designer,1.0.0,plugins/com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.designer_1.0.0.jar,4,false
com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.runtime,1.0.0,plugins/com.deltek.enterprise.system.reporting.client.birt.oda.runtime_1.0.0.jar,4,false


Result - your data source without "red" cross:

![2022-11-28 20_46_44-C__BIRT_4 11_eclipse_configuration_org eclipse equinox simpleconfigurator_bundle](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41593722/204367893-729d33ab-15e5-46c5-bd69-356607871c80.png)

@all:
Does anyone know why the equinox.simpleconfigurator have such behavior?
Which step or configuration is to set that the bundle.info will be created automatically?

title: Thick leader lines on pie chart after repeated Generator build/render drawImage
body:
We use BIRT in [Eclipse Memory Analyzer](http://www.eclipse.org/mat)

I have noticed that resizing a window which has a BIRT drawn pie chart goes wrong on high resolution displays on Windows.

The code constructs a pie chart using a PieSeries.

It is then drawn using Generator.build() and then using a new GC and a new SWT Image, Generator.render() into the Image before a gc.drawImage to draw the chart into a SWT graphics context.

If the window is resized then the build/render/drawImage steps are repeated as the build bounds will have changed. Each time the steps are repeated the pie chart leader lines get thicker until they obscure the chart. Then after 20+ redraws the leader lines disappear. 

See [Bug 581154](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=581154) for images [Thick leader lines](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=288866)

I think what is happening is the build step the [render code at Generator.java](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/blob/62d2ab909d7809c1a2942fb3d471f9427c38bd4d/chart/org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine/src/org/eclipse/birt/chart/factory/Generator.java#L1018) does an `updateDeviceScale` which each time multiplies the leader line thickness in the chart. As the chart is not rebuilt each time the leader lines double in thickness until they eventually overflow to 0.

title: NA
body:
Hi, Andrew. I love MAT. Let's see if we can fix this. 

You state: "high resolution." Is this relevant?

I fixed the ChartExamples view so that they can run without Eclipse running,  but I do not see any resize artifacts. Please see attached. 

How do you trigger the renderer? Are you rebuilding the chart every time?


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180969/204896158-c6889260-add5-473f-85fa-a39bb2b7acab.mp4


https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180969/204896184-9de92af3-2807-47da-b086-3ebbdf4cdf4c.mp4

title: NA
body:
High resolution is relevant - it happens on my Windows 11 laptop at 2560x1600, 150% scale in display setting, but not at 125% scale or 150% scale. It doesn't occur at 1920x1200 with 125% scale.

The line `final int scale = idr.getDisplayServer().getDpiResolution() / 72;` must return at least 2 for the problem to occur, so getDpiResolution() >= 144.

The chart is only constructed once. On each resize, the code does a  Generator.build() and then using a new GC and a new SWT Image, Generator.render() into the Image before a SWT gc.drawImage to draw the chart into a SWT graphics context. 

The problem is that if scale >= 2 then the scale code in BIRT is executed every time gr.build() is done and it modifies the chart each time, doubling the line thickness.

I can fix the problem by instead of doing in my code:
`       state = gr.build(renderer.getDisplayServer(), chart, bo, null, rtc, null);`
doing:
`       state = gr.build(renderer.getDisplayServer(), chart.copyInstance(), bo, null, rtc, null);`

Is this the right way to solve the problem?

title: NA
body:
I found the bug. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/180969/209402035-88b19009-9b3c-4b7c-bc6e-bcb46365a495.png)

title: NA
body:
> I can fix the problem by doing: ` state = gr.build(renderer.getDisplayServer(), chart.copyInstance(), bo, null, rtc, null);`
> 
> Is this the right way to solve the problem?

The chart is the model of the renderer. The renderer updates the model, so passing a copy will not reflect these changes in the original model. I'm not sure if this will have side effects.

title: Generated PDF ignores "line-height" CSS property for "line-height" < 100%
body:
We're using BIRT 4.9.0 for generating PDF reports. 
The issue we've faced is that generated PDFs doesn't respect the CSS property `line-height` in cases when this property is < 100%.

Debugging shows that the reason is logic in `LineArea` and `InlineStackingArea` classes. I will provide a PR which fixes this. 

Attached file is a sample` .rptdesign` template which shows the problem. 
[line-height-test-20221201-1915.zip](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/files/10135161/line-height-test-20221201-1915.zip)

This issue was present in BIRT 4.4.2 also.

title: NA
body: PR with issue fix: https://github.com/eclipse/birt/pull/1124

title: Extreme high number of connections when using SQL Server Driver
body:
There is a very annoying issue when using complex reports with the SQL Server Driver. For every single query a new connection is created. We are using a Wildfly 26.1.2 instance where birt.war is running to service different RPTDESIGN files. We have configured a connection pool to the database which is used in the design files using odaJndiName property. This way we can manage the connections that are made on the server. After we migrated to the new app server, new drivers, etc. we found that the connection pool kept clogging up. This only happened when running BIRT reports.

After investigating the problem it seems that in  org.eclipse.birt.report.data.oda.jdbc.Connection in the method getMaxQueries() there is a conditional structure figuring out the max number of statements. In the instance of our SQL server the max statements is 0 (unlimited) and the max connections is 32767 (SQL Server max setting). The conditional then will return a max number of queries of 1 !!!! This makes every single query trigger a new connection. Instead I would expect that this method always returns 0 in case maxstatements =0., regardless of the number of maximum connections.

I have fixed the issue in  a fork here:
https://github.com/roeltje25/birt/blob/4.9.0-fixed/data/org.eclipse.birt.report.data.oda.jdbc/src/org/eclipse/birt/report/data/oda/jdbc/Connection.java

that is for the specific version of birt we have isntalled. The issue is still there for the newer versions also.

title: OSGi Runtime: Opening report design containing a chart with design session is failing
body:
With BIRT OSGi 4.10 I can not open a rptdesign containing a chart via the design session, because a _MissingResourceException_ is thrown.

Sample Code:
```
System.out.println("Call openReportDesign()");
IDesignEngineFactory designFactory = (IDesignEngineFactory) Platform.createFactoryObject (IDesignEngineFactory.EXTENSION_DESIGN_ENGINE_FACTORY);
IDesignEngine designEngine = designFactory.createDesignEngine(designConfig);
SessionHandle designSession = designEngine.newSessionHandle(ULocale.ENGLISH);
ReportDesignHandle design = designSession.openDesign("/path/to/design_with_chart.rptdesign");
```

If the code is run, following error arises:
```
Call openReportDesign()
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError
	at org.eclipse.birt.chart.util.ChartUtil.<clinit>(ChartUtil.java:125)
	at org.eclipse.birt.chart.reportitem.ChartReportItemImpl.doCompatibility(ChartReportItemImpl.java:282)
	at org.eclipse.birt.chart.reportitem.ChartReportItemImpl.deserialize(ChartReportItemImpl.java:264)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.extension.PeerExtensibilityProvider.initializeReportItem(PeerExtensibilityProvider.java:512)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.elements.ExtendedItem.initializeReportItem(ExtendedItem.java:295)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ExtendedItemState.end(ExtendedItemState.java:141)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.util.XMLParserHandler.endElement(XMLParserHandler.java:177)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.endElement(AbstractSAXParser.java:610)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanEndElement(XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.java:1718)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl$FragmentContentDriver.next(XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.java:2883)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentScannerImpl.next(XMLDocumentScannerImpl.java:605)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanDocument(XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.java:534)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(XML11Configuration.java:888)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(XML11Configuration.java:824)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XMLParser.parse(XMLParser.java:141)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.parse(AbstractSAXParser.java:1216)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.jaxp.SAXParserImpl$JAXPSAXParser.parse(SAXParserImpl.java:635)
	at java.xml/com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.jaxp.SAXParserImpl.parse(SAXParserImpl.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ModuleReader.readModule(ModuleReader.java:94)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.ModuleReader.readModule(ModuleReader.java:210)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.parser.DesignReader.read(DesignReader.java:124)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.core.DesignSessionImpl.openDesign(DesignSessionImpl.java:228)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.core.DesignSessionImpl.openDesign(DesignSessionImpl.java:208)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.api.SessionHandleImpl.openDesign(SessionHandleImpl.java:199)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.model.api.SessionHandle.openDesign(SessionHandle.java:1)
	at de.test.minimalbirtapplication.MinimalBIRTApplication.openReportDesign(MinimalBIRTApplication.java:151)
	at de.test.minimalbirtapplication.MinimalBIRTApplication.main(MinimalBIRTApplication.java:71)
Caused by: java.util.MissingResourceException: Could not find the bundle org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine.i18n.nls_en_US
	at com.ibm.icu.impl.ResourceBundleWrapper.getBundleInstance(ResourceBundleWrapper.java:134)
	at com.ibm.icu.util.UResourceBundle.instantiateBundle(UResourceBundle.java:389)
	at com.ibm.icu.util.UResourceBundle.getBundleInstance(UResourceBundle.java:149)
	at com.ibm.icu.util.UResourceBundle.getBundleInstance(UResourceBundle.java:278)
	at org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine.i18n.Messages.<clinit>(Messages.java:39)
	... 27 more
```

It seems that this error happens, because the library jar file _ReportEngine/lib/chartitemapi.jar_ of BIRT 4.10 OSGi does not contain the file _/org/eclipse/birt/chart/engine/i18n/nls.properties_.

With BIRT 4.8 everything is fine. Probably because the file is present in its _ReportEngine/lib/chartitemapi.jar_.

Do you know why this fallback resource file is missing in BIRT 4.10?

title: Chart examples don't run standalone
body: The Platform must be running otherwise, the ChartExamples.main method does not run.

title: NA
body: See:  Thick leader lines on pie chart after repeated Generator build/render drawImage #1121

title: properties file missing in chart engine api

title: NA
body:
The properties file is not included in the jar. In all other similar cases, the properties file is included. I can't find any evidence that this was ever included but still, in 4.8 it is there.

I have updated the build scripts to include the properties file for this package.

title: maven repository for BIRT
body:
I am trying to upgrade birt runtime for my application from 4.4 to 4.10. But I have hard time to find the maven package available anywhere. Can you please consider to make birt run time package available in public maven repo?

Thanks!

body:

`<dependency>
		    <groupId>org.eclipse.birt.runtime</groupId>

		    <version>4.4.2</version>
		</dependency>`

title: NA
body:
Duplicates #625.

In the meantime, it's worth noting that - if you trust innovent solutions - you can use [birt 4.8.0](https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/innoventsolutions/birt/runtime/org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.14.0.v20180417-0825/4.8.0/). You may be able to hack together a set of dependencies for 4.9 from what has been published recently.

title: NA
body:
I tried birt 4.8.0 packaged under innoventsolutions. The issues I experienced were related that it packaged a lot of basic dependencies with older version. To be specific - slf4j - after upgrading it to 4.8.0, I got compilation error saying "java.lang.String cannot be converted to org.slf4j.Marker".
I tried the solution to exclude certain package path - but it didn't work well with multi-module projects.

title: NA
body: duplicate #625

body: In some cases, it is possible to execute javascript code on the server.

I don't know. It depends on many factors. However, the SCORE is probably a good indicator.

title: Regarding Jakarta EE 10 implementation of BIRT to work with wildfly 27
body:
Hi Team,

We have been using the eclipse BIRT in our product and we are planning to support wildfly 27 to our product and which is a  Jakarta EE 10 implementation. As part of this support, BIRT also need to be with Jakarta EE 10 implementation. It seems that the latest version of eclipse BRT (4.12.0) doesn't have the Jakarta EE 10 implementation. Could you please let us know if you have a plan for this implementation ? if so, any timeline.

title: NA
body:
Hello there,

To add some additional informations, what I saw not working on Jakarta EE 10 at this moment is the **Viewer Tag Library**.

When trying to deploy a project including the "viewerservlets.jar" with tag library enabled, it runs into lots of "java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError" exceptions.
By example the first one looks like :

> WARN  [org.jboss.modules.define] (MSC service thread 1-1) Failed to define class org.eclipse.birt.report.taglib.AbstractBaseTag in Module "xxx.war" from Service Module Loader: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Failed to link org/eclipse/birt/report/taglib/AbstractBaseTag (Module "xxx.war" from Service Module Loader): javax/servlet/jsp/tagext/TagSupport

And finally, the deployment ends with : 

> WARN  [org.jboss.as.ee] (MSC service thread 1-1) WFLYEE0007: Not installing optional component org.eclipse.birt.report.taglib.ParamDefTag due to an exception

The new Jakarta EE 10 specifications replaced all "javax" package namespaces by the "jakarta" one that I think causes all of these  java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError exceptions.

title: NA
body:
Thank you for your time and response.

Yes, you are right. 

So, viewerservlets.jar jar should implement "jakarta" namespace in order to support  Jakarta EE 10.

Thanks,
Kranthi

title: NA
body: Thanks for the analysis. Can you provide a patch? The [Contribution Guide](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) is here.

title: NA
body:
Hello Team
Please what is the status of this issue? In BIRT-runtime-4.13.0  classes in viewservlets.jar still have 'javax' imports instead or 'jakarta'. This is breaking our app server with java 17.

title: NA
body: We have not worked on it. Please, members of this discussion, provide a patch. The [Contribution Guide](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) is here.

title: NA
body:
I would just like to note that we currently are using Jetty10, which some parts of the Eclipse 2022-12 release rely on. A move to the jakarta namespace would require us to use Jetty11 instead.

I have, in principle, nothing against this, but it would probably require us to maintain two separate branches of BIRT since the javax namespace is far from dead.

Some of the tools we are using, like axis 1.4, rely on the javax namespace. We probably would need to move away from those.

'javax' name is proprietary and belongs to Oracle. 'jakarta' is the replacement open-source name for all 'javax' named packages.

The JDK does not contain, use, nor provide anything from the jakarta namespace nor will it ever do so, so there is no relation.

body: No, modules kicked in for Java 9 and only parts of javax were migrated to jakarta, i.e., only the JEE things.  So not to worry of course eventually one will want to migrate.  But I would plan for such a thing at the start of a release cycle.  Even the Eclipse Platform itself is only in early stages of such migration...

title: NA
body:
Hi, it is not exactly "clean" but for your information we are running BIRT within a Jakarta project on tomcat 10.x without issue. We use the BIRT engine and BIRT web viewer within our web application to run a variety of different reports. We certainly do not use all of the features that BIRT exposes, so this may not work "everywhere" or for "everything".

We accomplished this by using the tomcat translator to automatically translate all of the BIRT jars to Jakarta. In terms of third parties it was mostly okay, but we did have to also translate axis and make one api change there for Servlet 6.

There are some other peculiarities to our build as well, such as not using OSGI, subbing in maven central artifacts for the orbit ones where we can, some other dependency upgrades, etc. In addition the tomcat translator does other undesirable things to your jar files, such as stripping signatures.

Certainly would be some work to convert BIRT to Jakarta upstream. Simply commenting for anyone who needs to run BIRT on Jakarta sooner, it's certainly possible.

body:

with birt 49 we got the exception
```
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "org.eclipse.birt.data.engine.api.aggregation.IAggrFunction.getParameterDefn()" because the return value of "org.eclipse.birt.data.engine.odi.IAggrInfo.getAggregation()" is null
	at org.eclipse.birt.data.engine.executor.aggregation.AggregationHelper.populateAggregations(AggregationHelper.java:100) :+1: 
```
line is :
	`aggrArgs[i] = new Object[aggrInfo.getAggregation().getParameterDefn().length];`

The main difference between our 2 environments is  that in Birt48 pom we are using org.eclipse.birt.runtime_4.8.0-20180626-4.8.0.jar and in 4.9 a list of birt and eclipse artifacts from maven repo. Could one miss, be a "bad" one ? or is it a known problem in 4.9 ?

title: Add support for soft hyphens (SHY, Unicode 173) to Word and PDF emitter
body:
Tested with BIRT 4.3.0, but I think the behavior is still the same with current BIRT source:

Unicode Symbol 173 is the soft-hyphen symbol known as `SHY`.
The abbreviation SHY is fitting perfectly, because this symbol usually hides itself and only should be visible at the end of a line.

Some languages, German in particular, tend to use very long words, for example in chemistry.
In some cases, the text containing these words is predefined somewhere, e.g. in a database.
So it makes sense to store good possible hyhenation points by placing the SHY symbol at these places inside the word,
e.g. for a word like "kapillar­gaschromato­graphisch" this could be stored as "kapillar-gas-chromato-graphisch".
Notes:
1) There are more possible hyphenation points inside this word, e.g. "ka-pil-lar-gas-chro-ma-to-graph-isch", but not all of them good for readability.
2) I used the minus sign instead of the SHY symbol, because you wouldn't see it: The browser understands it and would hide it.
3) This does not mean we need *automatic* hyphenation. But if the text is already prepared for hyphenation, let's just use that info.

As far as I can tell, the PDF emitter does all the line-breaking logic inside BIRT.
So it should be possible to specifically handle the SHY symbol inside pre-hyphenated word and to consider it in the simple word-breaking algorithm.
It should also be possible to make this work in some way for the Word emitter. At least it seems necessary to replace a SHY character with `<w:softHyphen/>` in the XML output.

I'll ask my boss if and when I can get the time to tackle this.

title: NA
body:

title: No tags nor sources package for 4.12.0
body:
The [landing page's](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/) `README.md` says **Latest version 4.10.0**, but [the link to the latest drop](https://download.eclipse.org/birt/downloads/drops/latest/) underneath points to a **4.12.0** binary. In the repository, I see no tag for 4.12.0 (nor 4.11.0), and the [latest sources one can download](https://github.com/eclipse/birt/releases) are 4.10.0. The fact that there is no tag makes it hard/impossible to download the sources for the 4.12.0 release.

My expectation is that for every release there is a corresponding tag and source release.

Can someone please tag the right commits appropriately and provide sources packages?

title: Page break issue with tables in PDF emitter
body:
Sometimes, depending on the data (or probably depending on the exact y positions and heights), we see that in the PDF emitter output (created with `RunAndRenderTask`), page breaks in tables do not work as expected:

 - The bottom border line of the cells in the last row of page 1 is not rendered.
 - The table header row is missing on page 2.

See the following picture:

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7644776/214247686-a99b0a4c-4c6f-4823-b05a-13fd0a791bb0.png)

Expected output:
- A line below the last row on page 1.
- The table header on page 2.

As in this picture created from slightly different data:

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7644776/214248709-c4f8edcd-1cd8-42df-aedd-d2031985d81b.png)

The table itself is referenced from a library.

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7644776/214249119-fde75645-75a1-45dd-97cd-fb61765b3348.png)

It is just a header row and a detail row.
The first cell of the detail row contains a dynamic text item and a list item containing another dynamic text item.
Both dynamic text items contain HTML.
So nothing special here, from a layout point of view.
The cells all have a border:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7644776/214249713-aa90d53d-1266-4aaa-a4b4-3de5eb83840a.png)

Unfortunately I cannot deliver a simple, self-contained test case ATM.

The PDF is created with the BIRT BIRT 4.3.0 runtime.

I'll test with the current BIRT trunk and update the results here.

body:
> I'll test with the current BIRT trunk and update the results here.

The issue is highly depending on the y-position. I cannot reproduce it in our environment. So I'd have to create a report with exactly the same data shown, but independent of the database. This will take time.

title: Regression regarding image size (at least in PDF emitter)
body:
One of our reports contains a grid where the grid width is set and the width of each column is set and grid width != sum of column widths, so the given constraints are conflicting.
With the [latest release 2.1.2](https://github.com/triestram-partner/birt/releases/tag/Reporting-2.1.2) of our (patched) version of BIRT, the behavior changed in comparsion to an (unreleased) release based on BIRT 4.10.

The only code change which comes to my mind as an explanation is the Fix for line-height < 100% bug
https://github.com/triestram-partner/birt/commit/d65522c37dce93f5ffe63723452a03d83f71eec9

I won't say this is an regression *bug*, because this conflicting contraints are really an edge case, but it is an unexpected (at least for me) behavior change.

body:
>  The font is installed on windows 10 in the folder c:\windows\fonts

Are you absolutely sure about that?
And what are the permissions?

Windows has become more and more strange regarding the storing of TTF files.

You can also try to copy the font to a different folder under your control.
You can than edit a file `fontsConfig.xml` and add your folder (or even your specific file) there.
AFAIK, this file is somewhere inside `birt.war`. So you should be able somehow to edit this in your web server (I can't help you here).

title: Excel very Slow with large number of groups
body:
I have a report with a large number of rows (400k) and a large number of groups (80k).

I want  display data on a single sheet Excel.  (In the table properties ,my Page break is 600k )

**- To generate a report XLSX with 300K rows and  **80K** groups , **it s vers slowly**  ( 14 Hours )**
- To generate a report XLSX  with 300K rows and  20K groups , it s fast (5 Minutes)
   
 If I change page break to 19k , the report run fast with 300k and 80k groups.

    Any parametre to modify in Birt engine ?

title: NA
body:
Huge Excel files are not a good idea generally (not restricted to BIRT).
I can hardly imagine a valid use case.
You should consider other formats and other tools if your goal is to perform something like a database export/import.

title: NA
body:
Thank you for the quick reply.
 My goal is not to make database export/import.
 
 It's customer request .
 An Accountant needs to generate an auxiliary scale report  with Excel.
 The report contains between 400K and 1000K rows

title: NA
body:
Hi
14 hours do seem like a long time.
We would need a simple. reportdesign file with which the performance problem can be reproduced in a developer environment. Can you provide such a test file?

title: NA
body:
Hello,
This a single. reportdesign file with which the performance issue can be reproduced in a development environment. 
You need only create many groups data , more than 65K groups.

title: NA
body:
This customer request is still hilarious. Excel is not made for this.
Excel is made for *displaying* and *editing* tabular data of moderate size.
No human will ever look at sheet with 400K rows. At least I'd rather shoot myself.
And for automatic processing of thousands of rows, the Excel format is not well suited, because it contains way too much boilerplate. For such amounts of data, it is way more efficient to create and process CSV files.
Using BIRT for this task is overkill.

title: NA
body:
... but if you insist on using BIRT, maybe using more groups just means you need more memory?
Did you try using a 64bit Java with a *really* big heap size?
It could be that the JVM is GCing most of the time when available memory is not enough (sorry for my English).

title: NA
body:
**The LINUX machine has 128 GB of RAM and 8 CPUs 64bit.
This machine is used only to generate this report.**

I'm unsing **64bit java** with big heap size **102 GO  .** 
CATALINA_OPTS="-Xms6144m -Xmx102400m -XX:MaxMetaspaceSize=2048m -XX:+CMSClassUnloadingEnabled"
The JVM is not saturated. There is always available memory.

The client has a paid reporting tool that generates this large report. 
**The client  switch to BIRT ( Open source version).**
![JVM64-is not saturated](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24314808/220406992-40340b48-cc0c-4d91-95c9-c217ed5eb010.png)

title: NA
body:
Well, I daresay a Raspi 4 and a few minutes time would easily suffice if you generate a CSV report instead of XLSX with the right tool for the right job (e.g. a little Python script). I did this a few times.

Here I assume that the data source is an SQL database.

The idea is that you let the DB do the heavy lifting and select the data already sorted. Then you don't need to keep the rows in memory, the program can "forget" a row just after it was written to the CSV file.

Such a streaming process is much more difficult when you create XLSX.
I know that the SpudSoft Excel emitter supports special options for this kind of processing (I can't name them, you'd have to look at the source code), but I doubt that this works with grouping.

And reading/processing such a huge XLSX file will also need much more processing power and memory in comparison to reading/processing a CSV file.

Using the XLSX file format for this is just a waste of resources.

No offence meant. I know how clients are...
Maybe hearing that XLSX is not the best interchange format for mass data from a third party can help you convincing them to use a different format.

title: NA
body:
Hello together, I can only confirm my writers before the XLSX isn't an data interchange format and also the spudsoft emitter of XLSX won't help you realy. The core is based on the apache POI library.

But the common reason of the long runtime is the internal characteristic of XLSX.
Because the file format is an zip-file which includes different XML-files splitted into different context.
If you use such huge data and groups all data must be handled in memory and the topic is that the XML-document tree must be handled at all.

You can compare it with an large HTML-file which you try to run on your LINUX-128GB-machine with an browser.
The limitation isn't only the physical size. At the end each is fact that operations like search or adding of such structure needs more time direct depending on structure growing.

title: NA
body: My fork at https://github.com/triestram-partner/birt contains improvements to the spudsoft emitter, in particular the EXTRACT_MODE option, which uses a POI streaming API.  https://github.com/triestram-partner/birt/blob/tup_main/engine/uk.co.spudsoft.birt.emitters.excel/src/uk/co/spudsoft/birt/emitters/excel/ExcelEmitter.java - this might help in your case. But be warned, the fork contains other differences too. I can't give you an example, you are entering unknown territory here. Maybe the test code contains an example, I don't know...

	at org.apache.poi.xssf.usermodel.XSSFSheet.createRow(XSSFSheet.java:539)

Did you try with a page break interval much lower, e.g. 10000?
Keep in mind that it counts the number of details, not the number of excel rows.
There are additional rows for the table/group header/footers.

title: NA
NA
body:
I'd rather recommend to control page-breaking (=switch to new sheet for Excel emitter) with the groups themselves, e.g. to set page-break-before: always (or always except first) for one of the groups.
See the page break dialog for the groups.

Hello, it s good idea but I have three groups .

The client wishes to display the total (group 3) in the same tab.
if I break in group 1, I can't ensure the total in the same page ?

title: NA
body:
I'm not sure what you want to achieve. For me, the restrictions seem to conflict.

The original issue (slow performance) was solved by setting the render option DisableGrouping.
Then you hit the technical limit of Excel with too many rows in a single sheet, which cannot be solved by BIRT.

Thus limiting the rows on a single sheet is necessary.

The issue you described last is that the "sheet-breaking" does not work like you want it to be.
This is very different from the original issue.

I'll close this issue now to keep it focused on the original problem.

For the "sheet-breaking" issue, I propose that you create a stand-alone report which demonstrates the problem with a much smaller number of rows, a clear description of what the restrictions are and what you want to achieve, and create a separate issue with this information.
