title: Issue on prepared statement if the parameter is null (e.g. optional parameter, research result of #579)
body:
I analysed the old PR #579.
It didn't understand what the target in full it seems to me to improve the exception message to get it more readable.

But I was interested on the main reason of the issue, so I veryfied the testing report at the communication and started a deep research.
And the reason of the exception is I think an "old"-topic/"known error". The reason is that the query cannot be executed if the BIRT-parameter of a query-parameter is null.
The most common way is here to use an optional parameter and set him to "null value" (then we will get the exception).

The technical cause of the exception is the implementation of the jdbc-method on the prepared statement to set the "null" value with "isNull()". The problem there is that the parameter type should be fetched to set the value but the current implementation won't be supported through Oracle with the ojdbc-driver:

relevant implementation line at class "Statement", method "setNull":
`this.preStat.setNull(parameterId, pm.getParameterType(parameterId));`

My suggestion to fix it would be to use the standard way which supports oracle in combination with the current version.

![statement-setnull](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/7311e722-10d1-484f-a8ff-559a4af1a828)


I have done the tests in both versions of statements which was descripted on #579 and I tested it with Oracle V19 and MS SQL Server 2019. With the small change the exception will be avoid. Here my result screens:


![statement fixed](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/2e8dc7da-64af-4c43-9610-3748d530c9f9)


I would prefer to create here the according PR to fix it.
Any hint to improve the change or avoid the "doubled try-catch" is welcome.

title: NA
body:
I'm too busy to test it, but to me it seems reasonable.
I remember when I debugged this back then, it seemed to me that BIRT wasn't able to detect the type correctly.
Which confused me, because it should be straightforward to determine the parameter type without magic type because the type is defined in the rptdesign. But then again, it's Javascript...

The idea to test it with an optional report parameter is good, however, please test it with a sub-report, too:

Say with we have a table PERSONS containing colums ID (as primary key), NAME, MOTHER_ID, FATHER_ID
(First test: The ID columns are VARCHAR2(10), second test: The ID columnd are NUMBER(10).
For most persons, MOTHER_ID and FATHER_ID are set.
For an orphan, MOTHER_ID and FATHER_ID are NULL.
For other persons, maybe only the FATHER_ID is NULL.

Now we want to create a report like this:

Outer report: DataSet persons 
    SELECT *
    FROM PERSONS
    ORDER BY NAME

Inner report: DataSet parents
    WITH  params AS (SELECT ? AS MOTHER_ID, ? AS FATHER_ID FROM DUAL)
    SELECT persons.NAME,
                CASE persons.ID 
                WHEN params.MOTHER_ID then 'Mom'
                WHEN params.FATHER_ID then 'Dad'
                END as relation
    FROM params CROSS JOIN persons
    WHERE persons.ID IN (params.MOTHER_ID, params.FATHER_ID)
    ORDER BY relation

This DataSet needs two dataset parameters.

Let's use a Table Item for the persons dataset.
Add a new column.
Drop the parents dataset into the empty detail cell.
In the DataSet parameter dialog, use row["MOTHER_ID"]  and row["FATHER_ID"] for the two dataset parameters.

Test if the report works correctly for orphans or if one of the two parents is null.

body:

body:
I created an additional report with the loop tables based on string- and integer-id-columns.
The BIRT-loop works also with NULL-columns. This was working in BIRT-versions before because I figured out that here is the internal parameter definition of the prepared statement available and the original "setNull()"-method can be used.
(I researched it with the debugger,
be aware to avoid confusing: the parameter definition here is the definition of the SQL parameter meta data (JDBC/ODA) which is not the same object like BIRT-parameter-definition).

The good news the change will fixed such special kind of unaccessible NULL-column type
and the existing behavior is also given and will work.

So I will create a PR for it.

title: guava class included directly in birt runtime jar
body: Recently ran into a nosuchmethod and it turns out com.google.common.base.Predicate class is included directly in birt runtime jar. This class is also part of guava-xxx.jar. These two versions of this particular class are different. Wondering why the guava jar is not treated as a dependency for birt runtime? This is creating library conflict issues where opensaml comes into play as it calls guava's Predicate. edit: thanks @merks . Added images birt runtime guava

title: NA
body:
@rajn 

You ought to provide some level of detail.  E.g., where exactly are you seeing this?  It's really easy to copy and paste screen captures...

@speckyspooky 

One thing I found very questionable is the following approach of  copying Maven jars and embedding them as libraries in bundles: 

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/208716/8c7bce8f-703b-4a36-86ac-98a9e67fc5c3)

This _might be_ the probably which which @rajn refers, though I can't be sure.    In think in an OSGi runtime this is maybe not a big deal because the bundle does not export the packages of these libraries, but in a "flattened" non-OSGi runtime this could end up surfacing an **ancient** version of guava.  It's doing some funky thing that I don't understand:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/208716/e5ab0d2b-0597-4061-98cf-56217e37cbf0)

title: Why is 4.14 runtime much bigger than 4.13?
body:
I noticed that the `birt-runtime-*.jar` file generated from the current master (upcoming BIRT 4.14) is much bigger than the corresponding file generated with BIRT 4.13.

I don't understand the build process really, but to me it seems that the folder 
`build\birt-packages\birt-runtime\target\package\ReportEngine\lib` which is the base for generating the ZIP, 
now contains a lot of files which, judging them by their names, seem to be irrelevant for the runtime 
and instead related to the UI only, e.g. files like `org.eclipse.e4.ui.css.core_0.14.100.v20230701-0639.jar`.

Disclaimer: I've seen this in the `tup_main` branch of my fork, but I'm pretty sure this happens with the `master` branch as well.

For this branch, the ReportEngine\lib folder is now about 20 MB bigger with 4.14 than with 4.13.

title: NA
body:
This commit added a feature to the product that determines the runtime contents:

https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/commit/92c78b3eb97f956808fe42a2c9f22a3016226c10

This describes why:

  https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/pull/1342

One would not expect a "runtime" feature to have UI dependencies, but apparently it does.

It could take much work to figure how how to do it differently, i.e, to figure how else to ensure that the runtime is complete without being "over complete by adding missing things to /org.eclipse.birt.engine.runtime/feature.xml until the other feature can be removed from the product without breaking the runtimes.   And I haven't even got the tests that test the runtimes working...

title: NA
body: OK. I hope this doesn't introduce additional security risks.

title: NA
body: I expect the biggest security risks are the ancient 3rd party dependencies, not bundles that won't be activated anyway.   It certainly it doesn't hurt to hope, but hoping accomplishes nothing...

title: NA
body:
I'm fine with the status ATM. 
However, regarding "not bundles that won't be activated anyway": Maybe you and me know this (more or less), but some of our clients regurlarly scan the disks for DLLs/JARs with known security issues. Copying files which are not really necessary increases the risk of false positives, and then one has to discuss them with the clients IT security department again and again.

body: Indeed, I recall the log4j debacle.   That being said, I assume clients have budgets and such clients might collectively consider investing a very small portion of their budget on defense/BIRT...

title: Font aliasing not working for HTML text
body: This isn't a new issue, but it's a serious blocker for migrating from running BIRT on Windows to running BIRT on Linux: The font aliasing specified in fontConfig.xml does not work for HTML font attributes. I'll try to explain this in detail: The attached report output should show the text in the same style twice, but the second output using the builtin Times-Roman font instead of a subsetted Arial TrueType font as expected. [20230802-3134388.pdf](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/12239658/20230802-3134388.pdf) This output was created from a report where I specify font name, size etc. as report parameters and then use different ways to dynamically generate formatted text: ![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/15942895-33bc-45ad-a244-28f5717c0c1b) onCreate event of the first item (row["TEXT"): this.getStyle().fontFamily = row["SCHRIFTART"]; if (row["FETT"] == "J") this.getStyle().fontWeight = "bold"; if (row["KURSIV"] == "J") this.getStyle().fontStyle = "italic"; this.getStyle().fontSize = row["GROESSE"]; HTML source of the second item: "" + row["TEXT"] + "" BIRT is running on Linux (in a Podman container, to be precise), with no Arial TrueType font available, but we have Liberation Sans available: ![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/e6abbbae-1b01-40df-a699-27e3c3da9daf) And we have defined font aliasing in the `fontConfig.xml` file: ... ... ... The font aliasing is working for statically formatted items and it's working when we set BIRT CSS style properties dynamically, but it is *not working for styling using the HTML style attribute* `style='font-family:"Arial"'`. A little background: On MS Windows, using the Arial font for subsetting it into PDFs is not a problem, because it's usually part of Windows anyway, and the license allows it. On other OSes like Linux, Arial is not preinstalled, and I'm not sure if it ok to just copy the *.ttf files from a Windows machine. The Liberation Sans font is designed in such a way that it can be used as a good replacement (not looking exactly the same, but the same metrics). The reports have originally be designed on and for MS Windows, thus every single report uses the Arial font. Now I want to let BIRT run on Linux (in a Podman virtualization). That's why I need the font aliasing. Some of the reports show HTML formatted text which is stored in database column. These texts sometimes contain `style='font-family:"Arial"'` HTML attributes, because our users are used to use Arial and don't think about possible licensing issues. **So what I basically need is the font aliasing working for HTML font-family CSS attributes as well.** I'm not sure if we can call this a bug, though, because that's only what I'd need for our application in this situation. Others might say that using HTML style attributes for selecting the font is very different, because the font aliasing was meant to design a report *here* and let it run *there* (in a different environment), and it should look the same if possible, whereas HTML text containing HTML CSS font-family is specified on a different level and the current behavior is more browser-like. The possible workarounds I see for our application are: a) update the existing data once, replacing the HTML CSS font-family attributes according to our aliasing map, and change the editor UI, replacing "Alias with "Liberation Sans" in the drop-down list of fonts. b) Modify the *.rptdesign files etc, basically doint the first part of a) on the fly before handing the text over to the dynamic text item. Anyway, it would be nice if we could opt-in for using the font-aliasing map for rendering HTML CSS font-family, too.

body:
I understand your requirement. And by default it is the same kind of request to support other CCS-attributes which are coming from Text-element and the CSS-styling should be transferred to HTML and PDF.
This will needs changes on the emitter-level for HTML, PDF and so on.

Yes, you described it, this wasn't the orign target of the engine. So it is no bug it is a feature request.
But I understand you well. There are also other CSS-styles which would be very heplful.

So it make sence to keep this topic open till we have time to check it for implementation.

title: NA
body:
HTML span styling does work with dynamic text items, too.

The issue at hand is that font substitution as defined in using `fontConfig.xml` is not working.

You can only see this if your runtime environment is different from your development environment,
because inside the development environment you can only choose fonts that *are* available anyway.

But availability may not be given at runtime (in my example, Arial is missing on Linux), so that's when font substitution steps in.

title: NA
body:
I understand your issue of that based on Linux.

So I tested it in another combination. I used "Helvetica" on my report because this font isn't installed on my (Windows-)server.
The span-tag used the style-attribute "font-family:Arial;". The result was like yours that "Times-Roman" was used.
Next step, I added the font-mapping into ***fontConfig.xml*** with the following line:

```
<mapping name="Helvetica" font-family="Arial" />
```

But the mapping wasn't used. I started a debug research of the code where the CSS-attributes will be fetched.
The result was that the Mapping name must be "lower" instead of "normal"/"UpperCamelCase" notation.
(The font-family-attribute is fine.)
My retest with the following mapping was successfull on my pdf-result:

```
<mapping name="helvetica" font-family="Arial" />
```

Could you try please the same configuration with lower case:
```
	<mapping name="arial narrow" font-family="Liberation Sans Narrow" />
	<mapping name="arial black" font-family="Roboto Black" />
	<mapping name="arial" font-family="Liberation Sans" />
	<mapping name="times new roman" font-family="Liberation Serif" />
	<mapping name="courier new" font-family="Liberation Mono" />
```

Here you will get 2 screen of the debugged raw text and the created font-name value in lower case:

![rawValue](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/48329b37-3b9a-420a-8811-efbf22b2fe86)

![css-value](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/37497dac-1131-4777-bb31-2ae4eefa9d7f)

title: NA
body:
Thanks, Thomas, that is an excellent hint!

I haven't yet tested, but I I think I know where the lower-casing happens (and it is probably OK there, I don't know the CSS specification well enough, but probably the values are meant to be case-insensitive):

![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/c7b022f6-6b93-43d1-a591-d852728c6d47)

So I think a possible workaround would be to modify the `fontConfig.xml`.

OTOH wouldn't it make sense to make the font-searching case-insensitive generally? What do you think?

title: NA
body: I tested a report which contains a HTML dynamic text item. Inside the report definition, the item is defined to use the Arial font (statically). The HTML text is like this: Die Probenentnahme erfolgte durch oder auf Veranlassung des Einsenders. Die zweite Zeile ist dynamisch als Arial formatiert, zum Teil fett. With my previous `fontConfig.xml` (excerpt) this results in this output: ![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/37475796-c6ad-45fd-bbf5-7aa57c433af2) Once I added a line the output is now as I want: ![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/d88c9008-23ea-4b25-a831-0768dfa81b36) So using all-lowercase font names in the font-aliases section is a reasonable workaround, thank you very much for your investigation!

title: NA
body:
According to your note, I would confirm your suggestion to have synchronised behavior between
the CSS-font-name and the alias-name handling.
The current implementation is a little bit "special" because you can use the font-name in uppercase or mixed case
nd it will be transferred to "lowercase" for compare. But the alias-font-names (of the mapping configuration) won't be changed to lowercase for compare.

My suggestion would be to solve this "dilemma" is to change the alias names at the HashMap of the font-aliases to lowercase to. (The tests on my side was successful.)

If you confirm that I would create a new PR for it.

### Suggestion of change: FontMappingConfig - change "addFontAlias()":

```
	/** The font-family replacement */
	public void addFontAlias(String alias, String fontName) {
		fontAliases.put(alias.toLowerCase(), fontName);
	}
```
 
![font-aliases](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/a0a1c75a-b8a9-4f0e-93e3-a92e32b62a96)

title: NA

title: Enhancement to increase the standard image support data-URL & SVG-images
body:
On the latest usage of different image types especially "png" & "svg" also with the different usage types of URL-data like source path e.g. "http/https" or in kind of data-URL I figured out that that we have there options to optimize the image support.

Additional on it we have an dependency issue based on the usage of apache-xml-graphics because since version 1.8 the JPGE-transcoder is not longer part of the package. Therefore some svg-transformations (svg-to-image) won't be generated.

### My targets are:
1. Improve the standrad handling of SVG-images to get a common handling of svg-images.
2. Solve the issue with the jpeg-transcoder to switch to the png-transcoder
3. Implements more options to support URL-source-implementations
4. Synchronize the preview availablitity of the designer in the best way with HTML, PDF, DOCX, XLSX and PPTX

**Additiona information to target 1)**
In the first step the svg-images will be handled like the current svg-images which use the transformation into an raster image.
I know this isn't the best way but I will follow the current implementation and in a next step the switch to real svg-images can be done.
(WIth real-svg an separately implementation for each emitter is necessary.)


### Screens of the current designer preview with SVG-images & different URL-types
![designer-preview-compare-data-url-and-svg](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/61453d28-c311-480f-a3ad-0b5df96b0d7e)

### Screens of the current apache-xmlgraphics library
Source, StackOverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37899651/convert-a-svg-image-to-a-jpeg-image-using-apache-batik

title: Images with size unit percentage should be sized on the original image size
body:
Based on the discussion #1388 I started a small investigation on the BIRT-behavior.
The result is that the eclipse designer set the height on unit percentage based on the used font size.
The width will be set on percentage unit based on the container arround.

But the original version of the BIRT definition is that the image ratio of an image element if the unit percentage is used should be based on the original image size.

![resize-image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/48ada57c-9d17-406a-b3bf-28f520915024)

Therefore I would investigate and try to create a small enhancement to change the behavior on the folowwing elements:
- BIRT-designer
- Preview / HTML emitter
- PDF emitter
- DOCX emitter
- PPTX emitter

The plan is to have the original description (ration based on the original images) supported for raster images.

### The current presentation on the BIRT-designer
=> 1st row percentage unit & 2nd row according px dimensions:

![percentage-designer-error](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/16f7f298-9761-4c68-9ed5-972826da9730)

### The current presentation on the preview:
=> 1st row percentage unit & 2nd row according px dimensions:

![percentage-preview-error](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/5cc90283-0eb3-4313-b9f8-5c6cea279e70)

title: NA
body:
I think that part of the text excerpt of  that book (I've got one, too) is misleading.

Regarding the text "resizing an image ... typically results in a degradation of its appearance":

I think a better wording would be "may result" instead of "typically results".
This heavily depends on the output format, the type of the image and the environment where the report is read.
For example, in our application, "image" means "photo" in ~ 90% of the cases, "company logo" in 9% of the cases, and "icon" in very rare cases; and the output format is PDF in 98% of the cases.
The photos are stored in a database and it makes no sense to preprocess them to fit to particular pixel dimensions.
So the PDF report contains them with their native dimensions, but with a restricted physical size (preserving aspect ratio).
The reading environment may be a printed report or a PDF file. In the latter case, a viewer may zoom in, so it would be bad practice to store the image with only 72 or 96 dpi at a maximum width/height of eg. 16cm.

However, one reason to resize an image to lower pixel dimensions (before using it in a report) is the crazy pixel dimension that modern cameras and smart phones use (e.g. 30 Megapixels). This only blows up the image files and thus the PDF files.

Regarding "width and height as a percentage of the original size":
Even if EXIF metadata contains DPI settings, in reality a digital photo does not have a concept of "original size".
You could view it on a smartphone display or print a 10m x 6m advertising poster for showing it in an airport or shopping mall.
And AFAIK newer BIRT releases are not (or no longer) able to extract the "physical size" or "DPI" settings from the image metadata. BIRT just assumes 72 or 96 DPI (you know better). And then there's the `imageDPI` setting, and `fitToContainer`.

When we use an image as a company logo, things can be very different. Usually the physical size of the rendered image is (more o less) part of the report specification, and you (as a developer) can prepare a PNG (or SVG) file and choose all those properties in such a way that the result matches the expectations.

A particular difficult case is when you use images for DataMatrix- or QR-Codes or classical Barcodes and the report is to be printed on a label printer. Those printers usually have only 203 DPI or 300 DPI. This means that the size of a little bar or square, when printed, should precisely be a multiple of the the phyiscal dot size; otherwise the printer driver tries to "optimize" the image, resulting in unreadable codes.

Lastly (as a personal remark), I don't like percentage sizes. I always wonder what they mean:
For example, a percentage size in table/grid column isn't related to anything else, it only makes sense if you have several such columns, and their sum does not need to be 100%.
For an image, a percent size could mean "related to the available space" or "related to the 'original size'" (which rarely makes sense in my opinion).

I think we should not try to change the existing behavior, as that would break existing reports.
Instead what we should try to do is precisely document the existing image sizing algorithms behavior and how it differs between the emitters.

title: NA
body:
The "original size" exists for all images because it isn't based on "cm" or "mm" it means based on the pixel size of the images.
So each raster image has an original sized and the DPI define only how many point will be used per inch. At the end it has an impact of the pixel count but nevertheless at the end the width & height is given in "px".

I know that the usage of percentage to define width and height is (I did'nt use it on my self) not the common way.
So I'm completely with you @hvbtup.
But currently it is unusable because if you use percentage the designer display it in another dimension like the preview and also in another way like the PDF.
So I have test cases where the image looks shrinked on the designer, full in HTML and cutted on PDF - the same report and 3 different handlings.

Therefore from my pint of view the change would correct the current behavior to the correct way.
Because it was planned so to do it in this way but cuurently it isn't working.

I can also aks "It is a bug or a feature".

title: NA
body:
> The "original size" exists for all images because it isn't based on "cm" or "mm" it means based on the pixel size of the images.

That's what I call "pixel dimensions".

> So each raster image has an original size and the DPI define only how many point will be used per inch.

Yes. I think we both mean the same. We should be careful with the wording.

> ... but nevertheless at the end the width & height is given in "px".

I think that's not true for PDF output. There are no "pixels" in a PDF. Sizes are measured in units with a physical meaning (that's a bit simplified, because there may be scaling factors, but AFAIK doesn't use them).
As you did work with the code recently and know it better than I do, you may be right in a way, nevertheless.
It may be the case that BIRT does its calculations in pixels (or some other fantasy units) and finally uses a DPI value to calculate physical dimensions (measured in PDF units, I guess) from the pixel (or fantasy unit) dimensions.

> Therefore from my point of view the change would correct the current behavior to the correct way.

I think we'll have to carefully balance if we change the behavior or not (except for the appearance in the designer), because probably a lot of existing reports have worked around the existing behavior in ways we don't know.
So this would be a *breaking change* that requires most existing reports to be tested again and in some cases to be modified.

title: NA
body:
Yes, we talk about the same if we would be talk the full correct wording we would use PPI (px) and DPI (dots).
And at the end, yes the emitters transfer the original PPI dimensions into the DPI dimensions for printing.
On the screen level PPI and DPI is the same but on printing level it is not the same and the PPI will be recalcukated to the DPI for the (print) output.
I have seen it on the image size calculcation of the word emitter which is based on the PPI and will be transfered/scaled.

Your last sentence is good point and therefore I like the discussion before I change it.
My view to define the risk is:
- the usage of the percentage unit is very limited by default because in the most cases the stard units will be used
- the designer visualization is wrong
- the emitter vizualization is wrong on the given percentage values (e.g. height calculation isn't correct)
- dependend on the report implementations images will be cutted instead of displaying

All the points can be fixed with the change and the change implemented for "percentage" on element "image".
So we will have no impact on the other more common and standard units.

Yes, this change could have an impact on reports which use percentage units and designed around the issues.
At the end I woudl define the risk as a "minor risk" and we had an improvement like "quality of life".

With the change we are able to explain the behavior without the change we assume why we got what we see.

title: NA
body:
> All the points can be fixed with the change and the change implemented for "percentage" on element "image".
So we will have no impact on the other more common and standard units.

If you can assure this, then it's OK for me.

title: NA
body:
Yes absolutly. I will add conditions that the change handling will only be used on images with the unit percentage.

All other units must be unchanged because there a change would be a "nightmare" and all is fine there.
I will also do double checks of the changed areas.

title: Wrapped java.lang.IllegalAccessException when trying to make https request
body:
We are making https requests in our data sources to fetch data from our APIs. 

We've been using following code to achieve this: 
```
        var url = new URL(urlString);
	var uc = url.openConnection();
	uc.setRequestProperty ("Authorization", "Bearer " + params["TokenV2"]);
	uc.setRequestProperty ("Content-Type", "application/json");
	uc.setRequestProperty ("X-Date-Format", "dd.MM.yyyy");
		
	var inStream = uc.getInputStream();
	var inStreamReader = new InputStreamReader(inStream, "UTF-8");
	var bufferedReader = new BufferedReader(inStreamReader);
	var line;
	var result = "";
		
	while ((line = bufferedReader.readLine()) != null)

I searched the web and found this issue: https://github.com/mozilla/rhino/issues/462

... looks related. If it indeed is the same problem it should be fixed in Rhino now. I do not know which version of Rhino that Birt 4.13 uses, nor, if we have updated that dependency with Birt 4.14, but generally I would say: Test this in a 4.14 build and see if it works there.

Earlier we depended on an Eclipse Web Tools feature to pull this dependency, hopefully, this has changed with the work Ed did, earlier this year.

title: NA
body:
This is basically the same as #1138, a result of the modularization in Java 9 and is now enforced by default in Java 17 (this is probably not exactly correct, but should suffice as an explanation).

Two different workaround are possible (I tested both for similar problems):

Either you can write a little Java class that implements the functionality of the script and call this Java class from the script.

Or you can add VM arguments to your BIRT Java process which allow the classes to be used.

Eg. for a report which creates charts using JFreeChart I had to add

    --add-opens=java.desktop/sun.java2d=ALL-UNNAMED
    --add-opens=java.desktop/sun.awt.image=ALL-UNNAMED

The packages you have to specify can be seen in the error messages. In your case I guess it should read

    --add-opens=java.base/sun.net.www.protocol.https=ALL-UNNAMED

Maybe this results in a similar error message with different pacakes/classes, so maybe you have to add more `add-opens`.

title: NA
body:
Yes, the core problem is this part of the stack trace "(in module java.base)"
which means the jar is now located in a different "module" and not longer part of the Java-core.

But Rhino doesn't know that he has to search into a "module" therefore the jars cannot be loaded.
It would be great if we could update Rhino to this version and then we can test it.
Because there isn't any guaranty that the improvement will work in every case.

I have special reports too which use Web-Requests and currently I plan to create report-jars as external resources to handle this problem. But it would be great if I can avoid this step.
So @merks, it would be realy very good if you could find the time to take a look into it.

title: NA
body:
**Workaround option: tested**
I started today a test session for my we-request report (BIRT 4.12 JDK17)
with the workaround option "--add-options" according to @hvbtup suggestion.

The result is that the configuration is working. For the configuration I added the 2 following lines
at the end of the BIRT.in:
```
--add-opens=java.base/sun.net.www.protocol.https=ALL-UNNAMED
--add-opens=java.base/sun.net.www.http=ALL-UNNAMED
```

The both lines solved the problems:
```
class:	sun.net.www.protocol.https.HttpsURLConnectionImpl
module:	java.base
export:	sun.net.www.protocol.https
```
and
```
class:	sun.net.www.http.PosterOutputStream
module:	java.base
export:	sun.net.www.http 
```

Perhaps this would be realy an option at first to get your report running.

I see you work with JSON which is good.
In my case I got a xml-response and then I have to add another modules to the configuration
because also many of the xml parser classes and xml classes are separated into new modules.

title: Image handling with issues (special cases): 1) space at file-URL 2) grid cell with multiple images 3) svg encoded images
body:
Based of the changes of #1401 and the testing I figured out 3 other existing issues.

**The 3 found topics (independent of this change):**
1. file-url with an blank character/space cause in some situations illegal character exception
- fix: escape the blank-character before the url will be used like path

2. excel-spudsoft emitter get a class cast exception if I have 2 html-tag-images in 1 cell
- fix: at the according position check the class before the cast will be executed

3. data-url of svg which is base64 encoded but internal not URL-encoded, this cause an illegal argument exception
- fix: add try-catch-block to fetch the illegal argument exception ( #1386 )

title: NA
body: I will create a PR for the 3 topics.

title: NA
body: Fixes are merged to the master.

title: Remove Cassandra Scripted Data Source and Hector-PlugIn
body:
The special scripted data source of Cassandra should be removed.
The Cassandra data source is end of live and also the use connection client based on hector-plugin is inactive since 2015.

Based on the current implementation we have some integration issues with SLF4J (#1332), guava-classes (#1376)
and we have also 2 "Dependabot alerts" (level low & moderate). 

The hector plugin is inactive since 2015 - https://github.com/hector-client/hector
Therefor no further changes will be done on th current plugin.

Reference extraction is documented here:
https://github.com/triestram-partner/birt/commit/93f18da8eb8275ba08c1608a5f39eae916898d3b?diff=split

I will create a special PR to remove the "Cassandra Scripted Data Source" with the hector plugin.

(The change was requested the first time with #951)

title: NA
body: The Cassandra Scripted Data Source is removed with PR #1419

title: CVE-2023-34623: org.eclipse.birt.report.engine makes use of vulnerable version of 3rd party library 'jtidy'
body:
The following vulnerability is present in _org.eclipse.birt.report.engine_ as it makes use of the 'jtidy' library, via the JAR file at the following location:
_org.eclipse.birt.report.engine/lib/Tidy.jar_

The version currently used by birt.report.engine appears to be as follows (a 2009 release):
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/5311519/4baa7b85-7799-4c06-9a38-86fef7d1a2a8)

CVE: https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-fv2r-hw24-8rxj

**Note 1:**
The jtidy project is maintained at: https://github.com/jtidy/jtidy

**Note 2:**
Recent release(es) of jtidy have addressed the vulnerability (eg. version 1.0.5).

Would it be possible to integrate the latest version of jtidy via the above Github  project, such that _org.eclipse.birt.report.engine_ is no longer listed as being vulnerable to CVE-2023-34623 ? Hopefully the latest version is backwards compatible without any API changes required, although I am unsure whether this is the case.

title: NA
body:
If someone is going to fix this:

Currently, BIRT uses the JTidy library in /org.eclipse.birt.report.engine/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF:

    Bundle-ClassPath: enginetesthelper.jar,
     .,
     lib/Tidy.jar,
     lib/commons-cli-1.0.jar

The jtidy library the OP mentions is also available on Maven: 
https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.github.jtidy/jtidy/1.0.5

Probably it would be better to use the library from Maven.

title: CVE-2023-40743 - Critical Axis library vulnerability
body: The Axis 1.x library has a [reported critical vulnerability](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-40743) in it. The 1.4.1 version of Axis is included in Birt 4.9.0 and 4.13.0. This library is EOL and the recommended fix is to switch to a different SOAP library (like Axis 2.x).

title: NA
body: Do you have any plans to help solve this problem?

title: NA

title: NA
body: As I understand it, the 1.4.1 version in BIRT is one that fixes the CVE in 1.4.0.   While it would still be good to switch to Axis, 2.x the linked CVE does not apply.

body:

Apache Axis 1 is in some regard maintained,

title: Charts - inconsistent line thickness when imageDPI > 72
body:
The state of the singleton class [Generator ](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/blob/d72d5fb662e98279b560b4fd90acd4164e400907/chart/org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine/src/org/eclipse/birt/chart/factory/Generator.java#L117) is changed in its [render](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/blob/d72d5fb662e98279b560b4fd90acd4164e400907/chart/org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine/src/org/eclipse/birt/chart/factory/Generator.java#L1022) method : 
`fScaleUpdated = true;`

As a result, when we have several charts in a report with `imageDPI ` set to a value higher than 72, the line thickness is adapted only for the first rendered Chart.

This is a side effect of #1155

title: NA
body:
Could you provide a small example report of that issue perhaps with a screen.
It would be help me to understand the problem better and mybe I can debug the behavior there.

title: NA
body:
Thanks @speckyspooky 

I've created a simple example with 2 charts. The 2nd one is just a copy of the 1st, without any changes: [birt-issue-1428.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/12788712/birt-issue-1428.zip)

I've set the imageDPI to 300:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/90317691/b632bb37-5e34-4562-8db2-a742d761c114)

When generating the report using the engine the 2nd chart has thinner gridlines (The correct chart is the 1st one. I've set disproportionate gridlines thickness to illustrate the issue):
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/90317691/452a7805-c4e0-4ba9-b2fc-66ffbaf2d11a)


This issue happens with any output format, but I can't reproduce it from the viewer. It happens only when generating with the engine.

I've tried to debug it and the key is the change in the [Generator's render](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/blob/d72d5fb662e98279b560b4fd90acd4164e400907/chart/org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine/src/org/eclipse/birt/chart/factory/Generator.java#L1022) method. I could see clearly that the 2nd time it is executed (ie for the 2nd chart) the call to [updateDeviceScale method](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/blob/d72d5fb662e98279b560b4fd90acd4164e400907/chart/org.eclipse.birt.chart.engine/src/org/eclipse/birt/chart/factory/Generator.java#L1023C7-L1023C7) is not made because the state has been changed during the 1st call.

The problem is that this behaviour was solving another issue ([#1155](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/pull/1155)), so this has to be taken into consideration.

title: NA
body:
@wimjongman

Hello Wim,
I reviewed your change and tried some test with different options to fix the situation.
But I stuck in without a final solution.

The problem is that your change is working on the generator which is instanciated 1times and so your flag is working for the 1st scaling. Which is exactly what you needed for your issue to avoid scaling more and more.

If a report has more charts then the 1st chart will be scalled but no further chart because the flag is set on the generator instance. I tried to register the scaled charts to identify the scaled charts. But each chart is in every call of the according method an own object instance and so I have no repeatable identifier (same chart, but in all cases a new instance).

So I haven't a good idea to combine the common generator-instance and the recognition of the charts to avoid multiple scale.

Do you have an idea to handle it?

Thanks in advance!

title: NA
body: @wimjongman Do you have an idea for that?

title: NA
body:
I think that the best short-term solution to this is to move the updateDeviceScale(cm, scale) method to the GeneratedChartState class and have the fScaleUpdated state kept there as well.
render would then do : gcs.updateDeviceScale(scale)  instead.

 I can provide a PR for such a solution later today if you want.

title: NA
body: ... on a second thought GeneratedChartState is designed to be "immutable" (even if the chart elements are not) to create a method that changes that would be ugly. I need to think more about this.

title: NA
body:
Of course, this is the problem that we have 2 different situations where the old version and the current version works but not at the same time together.

The really stuped thing is that there is no kind of object registry of the renered charts. I tried that to know which chart was scaled for an report but the objects instanziated completely new which is ok, but there is no unique identifier of each chart like "id" or "uuid" (this wouldn't be the best, but we would have a way to solve it).

title: NA
body:
Quick and dirty : We could create a copy of the ChartModel and use the copy on all places in the render method.
```
Chart copyOfCharModel = EcoreUtil.copy(cm); 
...
updateDeviceScale(copyOfCharModel, scale);
```
In the test report that added 1ms to the rendering on my computer, and it worked. Haven´t run tests on that though.

title: NA
body: Sorry for the late response. Claes, if you make a quick PR with the changes you suggested we can see if the build likes the changes,

title: NA
body: Yes, we can give it a try!

title: Birt Metaspace usage
body:
I am using Birt Report 4.4.2 to generate transactional reports in PDF format. Currently, the service receives approximately 50 requests per minute. The problem is that over time, the response times and PDF generation speed start to decrease, as can be seen in the graph:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/16979318/503e7310-8d9a-4bd0-a78b-1288b101a4c7)

Initially, I thought it might be a problem with heap memory usage, but I don't see the same pattern there:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/16979318/4e0d58f8-9247-4733-b39a-2d32905a7243)

I do see a similar pattern in non-heap memory usage.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/16979318/118f6f14-615a-42d4-9de2-60e978f136d0)

And after the GC collection it is normal again

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/16979318/966e8687-1b64-4b55-9155-eb110913d3c7)


So, my question is why do metaspace grows so fast and if there is a way to avoid this and mantain a stable response time.

title: BIRT 4.14 PDF output of dynamic text which does not fit on the page
body:
Hi developers,

is the following change in behavior intended or is it a bug?

A grid or table cell contains a dynamic text.
The HTML is longer than the page.
The `Page Break` properties of the table row is set to `Inside : avoid`.
The `General` properties of he Dynamic Text are set to `Display : Block`.

In BIRT 4.8 the Dynamic Text starts on the current page (if there is no object like an image that prevents that).
In BIRT 4.14 the Dynamic Text starts on the next page.
To let 4.14 start the Dynamic Text on the first page like 4.8 the General properties must be changed to `Display : Inline`.   

Thanks, Reiner

title: NA
body:
I think this is a bug.
I stumbled across this myself recently.

The behavior is as if the dynamic text item has page-break-inside: avoid set.

body:
This issue might be related to commit 16290e5de52bd919485e6cf042eac5c8ef4b97a5

The goal of this commit was to fix BIRT [bug 562873](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=562873) PDF Rendering error with dynamic text item after page break.
This bug was introduced by an older commit, which I reverted more or less.

Part of the changes was:

![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/1915ab27-513c-4dff-ad08-7be4ef2fcd71)

My gut feeling tells me this is related.
But... Back then, I reverted an older commit without knowing exactly how it works.
Just "Reverting the revert" would introduce bug 562873 again.

**A PR which tries to fixes this issue should also be tested with the report from bug 562873.**

body: Sigh... If I use the previous condition in the if statement shown above, this solves this issue, but results in bug 562873 again.

title: NA
body:
Commit history related to this file that might help in understanding:

9827648a90f938b611ed1db6677b73e2df474ad6 (2009)
"Bug 28147 Page Break for contents in grid cells does not work correctly in PDF...":
This commit added the if statement which sets setPageBreakInside = avoid.

2257c417cf8980c4a40d02ae97853e5f4aa50c2f (2013)
"Fixed Page break added after large dynamic text within a table on PDF 53266":
This commit fixed avoided the page break by sharpening the condition in the if statement.
Unfortunately this resulted in bug 562873.

16290e5de52bd919485e6cf042eac5c8ef4b97a5 (2020)
"Fix BIRT bug 562873  PDF rendering error with dynamic item after page break":
This commit reverted the aforementioned commit, *among others*, resulting in the issue at hand.

So the situation is like this:
* There are two issues: bug 562873 and this one.
* We have got source code that fixes one of the issues but results in the other issue.
* Most of the other committers are busy, trying to get rid of outdated 3rd party libraries.
* ATM the situation with unwanted page breaks is still better than unreadable content.
* The source code is a djungle for me as well as for the other committers, I think.
* Unfortunately there is no high-level overview how it actually works.

I assume that setting `pageBreakInside = avoid` was not the right solution in the beginning.
But I'm out of ideas what to do instead.

@reiner-killet If you need this fixed, you should try to find a solution yourself.
As a workaround, you can try to split your HTML note into lines somehow and use a list item to iterate over them.

body:
I started a smaller research on the **original report** from your side Henning which cause the change.
Yes we have there an issue but the reason of the moved first line after page break is not an issue of the page break it is the "margin-top".
Because you set in your report 10mm margin-top on grid level and if I change the value then the first line is moved back.
The same effect is given if the "dynamic text" is used directly (without grid) and there is an margin-top. SO there is the same effect that the first line is moved.
So it seems for me that the original issue of it is the margin-top calculaton of the PDF-emitter at one of the drawText()-methods.

### Gird with margin-top and moved 1st line of dynamic text
![top-grid-dynamic-text](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/92c78a20-ca76-4294-bd8a-dfffcce7ef36)

### Danymic text with margin-top and moved 1st line
![top-dynamic-text](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/a988d6fa-18d4-4d8a-9201-e77f9deb5a71)

title: NA
body:
I think it is an issue regarding the combination of page-break and margin-top in the calculation of the y position for the first line.
If I comment the if-statement in AreaFactory.java and set the margin-top of the Problem-Grid to 30mm, then the first line is rendered even below the second and third lines:
![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/7644776/1901d803-dde2-4d46-93c5-a7fe996cf3d8)

title: NA
body: If I add a 1px border to the master page and set margin-top of the Problem-Grid to 30mm, then print the second page, I can see that yellow area starts 58mm below the page border-top, which is correct (28mm page header height + 30mm margin-top for the grid). But the first line is written approx. 25mm below the start of the yellow area. And the 1pt padding-top of the cell seems to be ignored.

title: NA
body:
If the "misplaced first line" issue from bug 562873 occurs is depending at least on 
- the space left on the first page
- the margin-top and padding-top values of the dynamic text item
- the padding-top value of the cell.

But I don't see a pattern.

title: NA
body:
I added a simplified example report demonstrating bug 562873 in extrem form. The first line is written even below the second and third line (assuming the if-statement is commented).
[lwk_prb2.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/12867495/lwk_prb2.zip)

title: NA
body:
I have a suggestion for an solution/fix. The reason at all is the thinking of the caluclation.
Because I figured out a part of the source code at LineArea-class which calculate the start position based on the container which is around the text.
But the problem is that with "page break" the calculation doesn't recognize the new situation and so there is at the end a kind of height-offset given which moves down the first line. This is very specific because on of the points is that the page-break was caused through the margin-top which is the cause of the break and the (logical) area is splitted so into 2 part 1st page & 2nd page but the margin- shouldn't be repeated again.

### Long text, short suggestion of LineArea:
- 2 new lines to reset the height to 0 if the text is splitted and the height is negativ:

![line-area](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/933b41b9-4226-4ae0-a60f-f681d43bd908)

My results looks good. Yes we need some further tests. The risk here is limited at the LineArea and has no effect on other area-container.
If this is working we should reset the AreaFactory to the original if-conditon.

@hvbargen 
What do you think about this fix-suggestion?

title: NA
body:
Looks good to me.

@speckyspooky 
Thomas, I suggest you create a PR (I'm really busy ATM with other things).
Please find attached a patch and two reports I used for testing.

The patch is basically what you suggested, plus:
- I added a comment referencing this issue and bug 562873 beneath your comment in `LineArea.java`.

Yesterday, when I looked at the current BIRT target platform I saw that we seem to pull those from the https://download.eclipse.org/oomph/jetty/release/10.0.15 update site now. A corresponding update site for 12.0.x does not seem to exist yet. 

I think that the additional Jetty bundles were:
 org.eclipse.jetty.webapp;bundle-version="10.0.11",
 org.eclipse.jetty.plus;bundle-version="10.0.11",
 org.eclipse.jetty.osgi.boot;bundle-version="10.0.11",
 org.eclipse.jetty.apache-jsp;bundle-version="10.0.11",

To support different EE versions: there has been some extensive restructuring of Jetty from 10/11 to 12 (https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/issues/7638) so the corresponding classes are in other bundles. If we can get access to all the Jetty bundles I suspect that the rest will be pretty straightforward.

After you get this into your workspace use the underlined toolbar button (also available as Help -> Perform Setup Tasks), double click the Module Target task (the p2 task doesn't need to run so note it's unchecked).  There will update the target platform using the latest update sites as underlined.

You can add things to the target platform simply by adding them to a feature or to a MANIFEST.MF;  even if that is an error at first, when you resolve the target platform using the above steps, those requirements will be taken into account and added to the target platform automatically...

title: NA
body:
I have put some hours into this, most of them to get a SLF4J2 binding in place. :-)
My conclusion is that we probably need the osgi-ee8 stuff to get this to work without big changes to how we set up the web application.

Here is a summary, from "the top of my head"

The OSGI documentation for Jetty 10+ is a bit sparse, but the OSGI documentation for Jetty 9 was pretty good: https://eclipse.dev/jetty/documentation/jetty-9/index.html#framework-jetty-osgi and is still valid to some point. With the OSGI layer in place, Jetty will track OSGI services for Webapps, Contexts, and even Servers and configure and/or attach them to running servers. 
This is what the BIRT Webviewer is doing. First, we create and register a Server, then we create a WebAppContext and register that as well. Jetty-OSGI will pick the WebAppContext and register it with the server., restarting it if required. It will also handle the configuration from the deployment descriptor (web.xml), setting up contexts and filters if needed.
But since the osgi-layer isn't available, nothing of this happens.

Some of the Jetty-osgi layer seem to be available in jetty-core/jetty-osgi . The OSGiServerConstants as well. I will look more into that tomorrow, perhaps all we need is available there.

All this is ofcause possible to do without the Jetty-osgi layer and I have done parts of it before, since the company I am working for uses an embedded Jetty 10 with OSGI, but has moved away from the Jetty-osgi layer. However,  there was a lot of pain to get it to work and we are not even using deployment descriptors.

body:
I have digged more into the build issue that I have and it seems like it is not available in version 4.0.3 of Tycho.

Here is the error again, better formatted this time:

```
Error:  Failed to execute goal org.eclipse.tycho:target-platform-configuration:2.7.5:target-platform (default-target-platform) on project org.eclipse.birt.chart.ui:
Execution default-target-platform of goal org.eclipse.tycho:target-platform-configuration:2.7.5:target-platform failed: 
The Maven artifact to be added to the target platform is not stored at the required location on disk: required
"/home/runner/.m2/repository/jakarta/annotation/jakarta.annotation-api/1.3.5/jakarta.annotation-api-1.3.5.jar"
but was
"/home/runner/.m2/repository/jakarta/annotation/jakarta.annotation-api/2.1.1/jakarta.annotation-api-2.1.1.jar" -> [Help 1]
```

I think that Tycho is confused by the fact that org.eclipse.e4.core.di has Import-Package headers for packages that are exported from two different bundles that have the same Bundle-SymbolicName ("jakarta-annotation-api") but with different version numbers(1.3.5, 2.1.1, respectively). That is a guess though.

With that said, un upgrade from Tycho 2.7.5 to 4.0.4 solved that problem, but introduced a new one. Maven complains about a cycle in the graph
```
Edge between 'Vertex{label='org.eclipse.birt:org.eclipse.birt.report.designer.tests:4.14.0-SNAPSHOT'}' and 'Vertex{label='org.eclipse.birt:org.eclipse.birt.report.designer.ui:4.14.0-SNAPSHOT'}' introduces to cycle in the graph
org.eclipse.birt:org.eclipse.birt.report.designer.ui:4.14.0-SNAPSHOT -->
org.eclipse.birt:org.eclipse.birt.report.engine:4.14.0-SNAPSHOT -->
org.eclipse.birt:org.eclipse.birt.report.designer.tests:4.14.0-SNAPSHOT -->
org.eclipse.birt:org.eclipse.birt.report.designer.ui:4.14.0-SNAPSHOT}
```

disabling that test makes the build of the Jetty-12 stuff work.

body:
I stumbled upon this issue when I was working with the Jetty-12 migration. The cause is that there are missing dependencies between the Axis bundle and java.xml.rpc.

These needs to be added:
```
 javax.xml.rpc.encoding;version="1.1.0",
 javax.xml.rpc.handler;version="1.1.0",
 javax.xml.rpc.handler.soap;version="1.1.0",
 javax.xml.rpc.holders;version="1.1.0",
 javax.xml.rpc.server;version="1.1.0",
 javax.xml.rpc.soap;version="1.1.0",

```

We currently seem to have access to two versions of Axis, one in the source tree at common/org.apache.axis and another one via Orbit. I guess that we should try to get the Orbit version updated.

title: NA
body:
Hi, if you are considering updating Axis to the latest Snapshot I have a suggestion. 

AxisServlet.doGet uses a deprecated method (line 265) that has been removed in the latest servlets. 

String url = HttpUtils.getRequestURL(request).toString();

This means that likely the BIRT viewer will not work when run with the Jakarta namespace if you auto-migrate it (eg: using Tomcat's tool) unless you replace this method with something else.

uk.co.spudsoft.birt.emitters.excel.handlers.AbstractRealTableRowHandler.interruptRow(AbstractRealTableRowHandler.java:186)

title: NA
body:
@ivkina Could you please provide an example report?

I have tried a first fixing but this will only avoid the issue of case 1) and your case 2) is the more complex merged-cell case.
The main issue is that the excel-emitter fetch a "row" which has no text value finally (condition 1) and the row includes a merged cell (condition 2). In this constellation the merged cell method will be called twice but this cause the error of this issue ticket.

In you case it seems that you have 2 rows which merged across merged cell (in a row 2) A2:K2 and merged cell B2:B3 in differend rows (row 2 & 3) and so you got the conflict because it is not allowed to have such cross cell merge.
In your case the issue is the conflict of cell B2 which is used twice of cell merge which is not possible.

It could be that your "row 2" has finally no text and so the internal row calculation goes wrong but there I would need an example of you.

And no, the issue isn't fixed because it is a complex case over all situations.

Woraround:
Try to avoid empty rows by using an unvisible character like " " (none-breaking-space) to keep the row.
(In the case above it was an option.)

title: NA
body: Thanks for your detailed reply! Yes, we use this technique of adding empty rows of fixed height to the report to achieve more controlled presentation and output. Let me check if condition 2 (merged cells) is also in place. The issue occurs with some reports but not with others. The problem is that we have more than 500 reports. Most of them are pixel-perfect/size-perfect page based layout so "empty rows" technique is used in a lot of places.

title: NA
body:
@ivkina I would be able to fix the exception but there is currently another issue because due to the merge, empty rows will be deleted in some special cases. And this cause your exception.

The workaround in your case would be if you use "dynamic text" or other kind of dynamic generated text-content then avoid that the result is empty or an empty string.
If you have NULL or an empty string you can add for example a "Non-Breaking-Space" (=   HTML-entity or key-board-code ALT+160) as result value then the line won't be removed because it is not empty and you got your row with your merged cells.

Currently I have no glu where the method is which cause the removed row.

title: NA
body:
@hypn0chka  & @ivkina 
I found the reason of the conflict and it is the combination of 2 different topics of the Spudsoft-Excel-Generator.
- Reason 1 is the row handling default of excel which removes blank rows by default.
- Reason 2 is the merged cells of excel.
And if a blank row with merge was detected like removeable it will be removed but the merge cells registered already which cause the error at the next line with merged cells.

The quick solution to fix it is to set on report level the user property "ExcelEmitter.RemoveBlankRows":
```
ExcelEmitter.RemoveBlankRows => Boolean => false
```
This configuration avoid for excel that blank rows will be removed (default is true).

title: Replace deprecated actions in our CI workflow
body:
GitHub complains over these actions:

```
The following actions uses node12 which is deprecated and will be forced to run on node16:
styfle/cancel-workflow-action@0.9.1,
actions/setup-java@v1,
actions/upload-artifact@v2.

 For more info: https://github.blog/changelog/2023-06-13-github-actions-all-actions-will-run-on-node16-instead-of-node12-by-default/
```

Also, Linux and Mac artifacts has changed extension from .zip to .tar.gz with in later versions of Tycho #1459 . Address that at the same time.

body:
I just want to say that, while you are free to use older versions of Birt than 4.9, none in the current dev team was involved in Birt when those versions were released.
A lot of work has been done to move away from legacy versions of Java. You will probably have better chances to get help with newer versions of Birt. From your original post, it seems like you are using a bit of a mix of Birt versions. Birt 4.9 requires JavaSE-11or higher. Next version of Birt will require JavaSE-17.

title: NA
body:
You wrote that:
>  I've tried replacing all the BIRT runtime libraries from 3.7 to 4.5 and even 4.13, but none of them worked.

That makes me believe that there is a mix of jars from different versions of the Birt distribution in your environment.
The error you have states that two classes from the same package are signed with different certificates, which also makes me believe that there are multiple versions of some jars on your classpath. Either that has been done by someone in your organization or someone else is trying to do something malicious.

Are you running Birt in an OSGI environment?

title: NA
body:
There are most certainly things in recent MongoDB that Birt 4.4.1 is not supporting.

It is important to understand that Birt 4.4.1 is almost 10 years old. It was released when MongoDB v2.6 was the most bleeding edge version. I do not know what version of MongoDB you are using, but v7 was recently released.
SCRAM, which is the default authentication mechanism in MongoDB was introduced in v3, which was released after Birt 4.4.1

title: NA
body:
My point of view would be to ignore the integrated mongoDB-driver and user the common oda-jdbc-interface of BIRT.
There you can configure all jdbc driver based on the driver manager and you can connect to the databse which you plan to use with the latest driver from the database.
Then you are independent in full, you are able to use the latest database driver. And in best case this would help you to fix the issue.

title: BIRT 4.14: After "Jetty 12" migration the web-viewer of the HTML-preview is crashed in design and functionality
body:

title: NA
body:
If you want to understand why this solution "works" you can change back those lines and set a breakpoint in org.eclipse.jetty.ee8.nested.ContextHandler.checkAlias() . You will see that Jetty refuses the request to resources which are not direct. This includes symlinks and "relative" directories.

The magic here is the .normalize() call, which does not exist on URL, hence the conversion to URI and back. 

What I really would like to do is use an URLResource to the bundleentry as baseResource on the WebAppContext. That used to work in Jetty-10 but does not work any longer. I suspect that line 650 in org.eclipse.jetty.server.handler.ContextHandler
```
      if (!Resources.isReadable(baseResource))
```
is wrong. Think that it should be
```
      if (!Resources.isReadableDirectory(baseResource))
```
instead. I have not checked with the Jetty guys though.

title: NA
body:
@claesrosell the URL<>URI fix breaks report preview (not sure what else) in installs with a space in the path, at least on Windows. Can be reproduced with the BIRT 4.15 All-in-one distribution. 

1. Unzip BIRT all-in-one to a location which has a space in the path.
2. Create a report project and a new report - even a blank report will do.
3. Use the preview button on the toolbar to, "View Report as PDF", "View Report in Web Viewer", etc. 
4. You should see errors in the log around not being able to start the application server, the crux of it is that the URL to URI conversion will fail if there's a space in the path:

java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in path at index 34: file:/C:/EclipseInstalls/birt-4.15 AIO/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.birt.report.viewer_4.15.0.v202403270652/birt/
	at java.base/java.net.URI$Parser.fail(URI.java:2995)
	at java.base/java.net.URI$Parser.checkChars(URI.java:3166)
	at java.base/java.net.URI$Parser.parseHierarchical(URI.java:3248)
	at java.base/java.net.URI$Parser.parse(URI.java:3196)
	at java.base/java.net.URI.<init>(URI.java:645)
	at java.base/java.net.URL.toURI(URL.java:1220)
	at org.eclipse.birt.report.viewer.utilities.ViewerWebApp.start(ViewerWebApp.java:59)

Workspace error [log](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/14853454/default.log)

body:
A bit OT, but...

If using an installation path *without* spaces is a workaround, then I wonder if fixing this is worth the effort.

Those who use spaces in directory names (at least on Windows) are looking for trouble.
This is one thing developers on Windows learn pretty soon.
There's a reason why e.g. the directory is called c:\users and no longer "C:\documents and settings".

OTOH, errors like this always smell like a security issue (missing or wrong or double escaping when writing or parsing data).

title: Update the BIRT setup to specialize how the target platform is generated
body:
Specifically we want to use the following new capability supported by Oomph's targlets:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/issues/40

I.e., there are cases in the generated target platform where we need to specify the unit version such that that we (Tycho) can include more than one version of the same bundle symbolic name in the target platform or can include an older version in the target platform.

title: NA
body:
@speckyspooky @claesrosell 

This change ensures that the generated target is correct without manual changes.  Unfortunately once versions are hard-coded, they need to be updated when there are version changes it the repositories from which the target platform is resolved.  But that's accomplished simply by performing the targlets task in the IDE and checking in the generated target.

The idea is that the setup specifies which units should have versions:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/208716/c4e26d31-91ae-489f-a092-2a7de7a11801)

And then the generator will produce these:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/208716/707627ca-780f-4f50-8eec-8fc0e794d30c)
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/208716/7326cd53-8f85-4f50-b5ec-e81e10246bc6)

Of course you need to pull, and to perform the p2 task to update the IDE to install the newer targlets bundle that does this generation step.

title: PdfEmitter, Enhancement: Enable options to set the PDF/Version & archiving formats PDF/A (A1A & A1B)
body:
### The target is to support different PDF-versions and PDF archive formats PDF/A (A1A & A1B)

Based on openPDF version 1.3.30 the following features will be available:
• setting of the PDF-version: 1.3 till 1.7
• setting of the PDF/A-version: A1A & A1B
• settong of the PDF/A-version: PDF.X32002

The default of the PDF creation won't be changed.
The new options will be activated only with the configuration of the according user properties.

### The following user properties will be available on the PdfEmitter:

**PdfEmitter.Version**, String, enumeration
• supported values: 1.3. 1.4, 1.5, 1.6, 1.7
• default: 1.5

**PdfEmitter.Conformance**, String, enumeration
• supported values: PDF.A1A, PDF.A1B, PDF.X32002
• default: PDFXNONE
• PDF.A1A & PDF.A1B overwrite the configured PDF-version with PDF-version 1.4

**PdfEmitter.IccProfileFile**, String, file path
• path to the ICC color profile
• default: sRGB IEC61966-2.1

**PdfEmitter.IccColorType**, String, enumeration
• supported values: RGB, CMYK 
• default: RGB

**PdfEmitter.PDFA.AddDocumentTitle**, Boolean
• false, avoid the title at document / true, add the title at document (openPDF 1.3.30: PDF/A will be invalid)
• default: false
• **Workaround: openPDF 1.3.30 issue** on creating the PDF/A title, the tag "dc:title" is invalid due to missing language-atrribute at the title content

**PdfEmitter.PDFA.FallbackFont**, String, font file name
• path of an alternative installed font name which can be used instead of an not mebeddable font
• default: null


The PDF/A results are tested and validated with 3 different PDF/A validators:
• pdfforge.org
• avepdf.com
• veraPDF

For the testing the results of 3 different basic test cases was used incl. images (direct & background images),
the basic tests are:
• Version: PDF/A1A
• Version: PDF/A1A with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
• Version: PDF/A1B with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
(• Version: PDF with configured PDF-version is tested and validated with the AdobeReader details dialog.)

### First results of the new options, PDF/A1A with fallback font to be a valid PDF/A document:
- PDF-document
[pdf_enhancement_version_PDF_A1A_FBfont.pdf](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/13261055/pdf_enhancement_version_PDF_A1A_FBfont.pdf)
- Validation screen of "veraPDF"
![verapdf-pdf-a1a-fbf](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/dec7d5e7-c777-46a6-bb3e-c9ad5ce5ba21)


### Attached the following test reports are given:
• 4 test reports of:
- Version: PDF with configured version 1.7
- Version: PDF/A1A
- Version: PDF/A1A with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
- Version: PDF/A1B with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
[pdf_enhancement_test_reports.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/13261049/pdf_enhancement_test_reports.zip)


### Attached the following documentation is given:

• 4 pdf documents of
-  Version: PDF with configured version 1.7
- Version: PDF/A1A
- Version: PDF/A1A with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
- Version: PDF/A1B with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
[pdf_enhancement_documents.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/13261051/pdf_enhancement_documents.zip)


### Attached the following PDF/A validation documentation is given:
• 3 screens of each PDF/A-validator of the results of the PDF/A-documents
- Version: PDF/A1A
- Version: PDF/A1A with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
- Version: PDF/A1B with fallback font of unembeddable fonts
[pdf_enhancement_validation_documentation.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/files/13261048/pdf_enhancement_validation_documentation.zip)

title: NA
body:
This is definitely a step into the right direction.

I'm not sure about some details, though.

First of all, would it be possible to also create PDF/A-3 (or at least in a later step?)
That would simplify creating ZUGFeRD aka Factur-X invoices (ATM I am Javascript to create an invoice XML file on the fly while generating the PDF report and then use a post processing step to convert the PDF and XML files to a ZUGFeRD file). ZUGFeRD is based on PDF/A-3.

Next, I'm not sure about PDF/A-1a (EDITED: correct is 1a (a for accessible) instead of 1b (b for basic).
Do you really create a tagged PDF or just a dummy tag structure?
Or are the validators just not properly checking this?
You know, PDF/UA also requires a properly tagged PDF.

If the PDF is not properly tagged, it would be better to not allow declaring the PDF to be PDF/A-1b conformant.

Regarding the title and language:
I think defining a language property (which would be like an inheritable CSS property) would be a good idea.
In the easiest case, one would define the language at the report level.

Regarding font handling:
I think when the fallback font actually has to be used, that is an issue with the report design, because the report will not look as intended. There should be an option to treat this as an error and add this to the error list (which allows the caller to detect this problem).

title: NA
body:
I'm aware of the topic with PDF/A-3 and the ZUGFeRD-invoice-method of german governance agencies.
So I'm checked all this details before.

- This change is from my side only the first steps and open this option for further PDF/A-levels.

- openPDF 1.3.30 support: PDF/A-1a & -1b, currently there is no PDF/A-3 support given

- openPDF tagged PDF: this is the standard mechanism of openPDF (real structur, no dummy, no special implementation here)

- The validator checks if the structure is a valid tagged structure. If the structure is not given then it isn't a valid PDF/A.

- Language of "dc:title" couln't be set by default with CCS-properties on report level, because there are special values according der PDF-definition. But the main issue is that there is no option given to write the XMP metadata (=XML structure) in the right way. I have done it but the problem is that the **structure includes the PDF-creation date and also the PDF-modification date** and the validation rules means that these values must be equal to the date stamps at the PDF-document (, make sense).
But the datetime stamps cannot be in sync because if I write the XMP metadata I will have another stamps like on the PDF-document because it will be created later and currently there is no simple way to set the datetime stamps directly.
All documented mechanism are based on a physical stored file which can be use to overwrite the properties (post-processing).

- Fallback font: Yes, the responsibility of the fonts is a task which is located on the report-developer. But during the development and also for the migration from existing reports it will help to implements and migrate the reports. This value isn't set by default so you would get an invalid pdf with the standard stacktrace into the PDF-document (based on text level, not like PDF-written text).

title: NA
body:
> The validator checks if the structure is a valid tagged structure.
> openPDF tagged PDF: this is the standard mechanism of openPDF (real structur, no dummy, no special implementation here)

I cannot believe this.

AFAIK calling `writer.setTagged()` merely *declares* that the document is tagged, but it doesn't add the tag structure AFAIK actually.
Otherwise we could have PDF/UA "for free" (see #1234).

You can use the PAC 2021 (PDF Accessibility Checker) to actually see the tag structure.
https://pdfua.foundation/de/pac-2021-der-kostenlose-pdf-accessibility-checker/

title: NA
body:
I have not set the the structure will be a full representation of all elements which are included on the DPF-document.
The PDF-document will be marked as tagged and the master structure internally will be created (no dummy).
Yes, would be more to do to have all tagged at the end.

But this is not my target.
The target is to get an option on BIRT that we can create PDF/A (1a & 1b) as a standard function.
My target currently is not to create PDF/A-3 and not to create PDF/UA.

These topics are steps for the next level.

title: NA
body:
Even though the validators say that the generated PDF is valid PDF/A-1a, this is not the case.
The "a" stands for accessibility and this requires a complete tag structure (just as in PDF/UA).
https://www.pdfa.org/wp-content/until2016_uploads/2011/08/das_bessere_pdfa-1b.pdf

If we add an option to create (seemingly) PDF/A-1a, people would of course think that BIRT supports PDF/A-1a.
But this isn't the case yet.

This topic is very important for the future of BIRT and thus I think the output should not "lie" by stating it's PDF/A-1a conformant when it isn't really.

So, in a first step we should only support PDF/A-1b ("b" for basic profile).

Adding support for PDF/A-1b (and for PDF/UA, by the way) will be easy once we can create tagged PDF.

title: NA
body:
@hvbtup 
But this isn't the same. The PDF/A1a ist different like PDF/UA. all PDF/UA-documents are vailid PDF/A1a documents but not all PDF/A1a documents are valid PDF/UA.

The PDF/UA conformance needs according to your explanations more details and the full tagged structure.
I used your tool and one thing was found that the "dc:title" isn't listed. But this is only a requirement to be PDF/UA conform but not to be PDF/A1a conform.

The PDF/UA stanards is a subset of PDF/A1a and PDF/UA is more restrictive instead of PDF/A1a.
So it isn't correct to say that the PDF/A1a isn't valid.

So I checked also a PDF/A1a with the wrong "dc:title" definition with the added Title but the unnoted language-attribute.
All 3 validators give an error because the title-definition is wrong. Your PDF/UA-checker means all is fine.

Currently my point of view is that the PDF/A1a version is a valid option.
Yes, it is not PDF/UA conform because for that there are some open point.

But you can test the created PDF/A1a documents from my demo-zip-file and you will finde,
that 3 error types are given of PDF/UA which means "dc:title" unset, "DisplayDocTitle" is unset, PDF/UA identifier not found and an operation "cm" was used which is not allowed. This is coret of PDF/UA but not required on PDF/A1a.

title: NA
body:
I have tested some further PDF/A-validators and here is a result which represents the difference between PDF/A-1a & PDF/UA-1. So I think our PDF/A-1a based on openPDF is a valid option.

![PDF-A-1a-validation](https://github.com/eclipse-birt/birt/assets/41593722/c8a7f1f3-edaf-4f4f-8219-fa87ff91a3b5)

Additional tested validators
- https://bfo.com/blog/2017/11/08/verify_pdfa_online/
- https://www.pdfen.com/pdf-a-validator
- https://online.visual-paradigm.com/de/online-pdf-editor/pdfa-validator/
- https://pdfrecover.herokuapp.com/pdfaconvert/

title: NA
body:
I don't own a copy of the EN ISO 19005 standard, so probably you are right and it only means that the reading order is OK.

I tested your document `pdf_enhancement_version_PDF_A1A_FBfont.pdf` with an evaluation version of a commercial tool from the Swiss PDF Tools AG if it conforms to PDF/A-1a.

This tool says:
```
- PDF: Graphics operator cm is not allowed in text object. (content of page on page 1)
Document conforms to PDF/A-1a: false
```

The validator does not complain about the missing tag structure, although this structure is empty (as can be seen with PAC 2021), so that's ok for me.

The same test result also for PDF/A-1b conformance.
Other validators I used earlier (when I used Apache PDFBox to convert the BIRT PDF to PDF/A-1b) did not say anything about the `cm` operator, so I guess this is a minor issue in reality.

Probably many documents claiming PDF/A1-a (or PDF/A1-b) conformance aren't actually conformant, so while we know that there are issues left (like the `cm` operator and the title), I'm fine with your PR.

title: NA
body:
@wimjongman 
If we mention this in the release notes for 4.14, we must make it clear that the generated PDFs are not really accessible.

title: NA
body: This issue is the release note.

title: NA
body:
@hvbtup  & @wimjongman 

I prefer that we add the new option on the release notes and additional on it we should not that the PDF/A* will be genereated with "openPDF version 1.3.30". So it is full transparent which library is used to generete the PDF/A.

I agree that we should add the hints PDF/A1b = ok, PDF/A1a with limitation based openPDF.

At the end with my experience in the past and you Henning that PDF/A is complex and one of the main issue is to have a good generator of PDF/A and also to have a good validator.

I tested with "https://www.pdf-online.com/osa/validate.aspx" agaian and there is noted the "cm"-operator and the issue with the "dc:title".

So we have know 9 validators of PDF/A1a with 7time=ok, 1times = faild due to "cm", 1times failed due to "cm" and "dc:title" (if it used). And all this differences of a standard which was published 2005.

title: NA
body:
One of the main problems with standards like EN ISO 19005 is that they are not open source.
So you have to pay to read them.
Many developers are not willing to or cannot afford to do this (particular in the open source eco system), and so they don't know the exact content of the standards.
Apart from that, writing a validator that validates e.g. the tag structure *is* complicated.
I think that's why different software producing PDF or validating PDF shows different results.

For example, I was not able to find a statement that `cm` is not allowed or an explanation why `cm` is not allowed in PDF/A in the public internet.
